Peanut butter can be used to help bind up other medications in the mouth. Used with pistachios as a massage oil. Nuts, in general, are high in fat, but most of it is unsaturated and has not been shown to be a major contributor to obesity if eaten in moderation. Nuts can provoke severe and even life-threatening reactions in allergically sensitive individuals.


 

 

PEAR

Antioxidant. Diuretic. Anti-ulcer. Lowers blood sugar levels. Peel extracts may be helpful in the treatment of diabetes and hypertension. Good source of Vitamin C which boosts the immune system, helps lower blood pressure, and has been used in the prevention and treatment of many cancers. Pear extracts and juice may be helpful in the treatment of alcoholic hangovers. Helps reduce the appearance of varicose veins. Red pears contain anthocyanins which may lower ones risk for colon cancer. Anthocyanins may also offer protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Pear consumption may be protective against urinary stone formation. Consuming pears can be helpful in decreasing the concentration of alcohol in the blood. High in fiber which helps increase elimination. Helpful for the obese. Pears contain pectin that encourages the growth of beneficial bacteria in the large intestine, and also helps lower cholesterol and bind up toxins (e.g. lead) in the body for removal. Pear juice is often the first juice given to infants because it is hypoallergenic. Used in facial masks to improve complexion.

 

 

 

PECAN

Among the highest nuts in antioxidants. Pecans are a good source of protein and zinc. Zinc is vital for a healthy immune system, skin repair injuries, the digestion of starchy food, thyroid hormone metabolism, and regulation of the prostate gland. Pecans are a good source of magnesium, which is a natural tranquilizer and helps the body to regulate cholesterol and blood sugar levels. Magnesium is also good for relief of migraines and helps slow bone loss. Pecans are also rich in fiber which helps increase elimination. Lowers LDL and total cholesterol. Shown to increase beneficial HDL cholesterol levels. Nervous system tonic. Rich in arginine, an amino acid which has been shown to increase the bodys production of nitric oxide. Nitric oxide helps dilate blood vessels, lower blood pressure, and improve blood circulation to the heart, brain, and bladder. Arginine therapy has also been used to treat lead intoxication and reduce the parasite burden in the treatment of severe malaria and leishmaniasis. Cancer cell and tumor inhibitor. Pecans are rich in ellagic acid, which is thought to be responsible for the anti-cancer effect. Ellagic acid, a neuroprotective and gastroprotective compound, has also shown some anti-malarial and anti-epileptic properties. Ellagic acid may also be helpful in promoting hair growth in testosterone-induced alopecia. Compounds in pecan bark can lower blood sugar levels. Extracts of pecan nut shells have been used in the treatment of alcohol-induced liver damage. A poultice of pecans and walnuts can be used to treat headaches. Pecans are higher in fat than most other nuts. Nuts, in general, are high in fat, but most of it is unsaturated and has not been shown to be a major contributor to obesity if eaten in moderation.


 

 

PENNYROYAL

Colds and fever reliever. Used externally as a wash for skin afflictions such as scabies, psoriasis, hives, shingles, measles, mumps, and chickenpox. Diaphoretic. Used in internal cleansings to increase the body's ability to sweat out toxins. Promotes menstruation. Provides pain relief from headaches and toothaches. Alcoholic infusions have been used to treat fainting, asthma, hysteria, gout, asphyxia, paralysis, and flatulence. Pennyroyal extracts have been used to inhibit the corrosion of steel. Pennyroyal essential oil is highly toxic and can cause liver and kidney failure. It can also induce nerve damage, convulsions, and burning of the throat. Pennyroyal is not recommended for pregnant women as it can also induce labor contractions and terminate pregnancies. Some deaths have been reported.

 

 

PEONY

Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Remedy for jaundice, kidney, and bladder problems. Root tea extracts treat gout and asthma. Helps lessen the pain and swelling of traumatic injuries. White peony has been used in the treatment of muscle cramps. Red peony extracts treat pancreatitis and help relieve arthritic pain and inflammation. May also reduce allergic symptoms caused by pollen. Protects nerves and inhibits convulsions. White peony extracts may help promote peripheral nerve regeneration. Chinese peony is used to treat depression and rheumatoid arthritis. Chinese peony seed extracts are also cancer cell inhibitors. Studies indicate that both red and white peony root extracts may be helpful in the treatment of hypertension, atherosclerosis, myocardial infarction, rheumatoid arthritis, chronic viral hepatitis, dysmenorrhea, and polycystic ovarian syndrome. Peony seed oil has been shown to significantly lower total serum cholesterol, harmful LDL, and triglyceride levels. The seed oil has also been shown to be protective against obesity-induced non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

 

 

PEPPER

 

 

SEE: BELL PEPPER OR BLACK PEPPER OR CHILI PEPPER

 

 

 

PEPPERMINT

Rich in antioxidants. Antiviral. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Antispasmodic. Decongestant. Analgesic. Antimicrobial. Inhibits herpes viruses. Remedy for indigestion, heartburn, nausea, flatulence, vomiting, coughs, pulmonary complaints, and colds. Extracts have been used to relieve nasal symptoms in allergy patients. Promotes sweat to break fevers. Stimulates circulation and the flow of bile to the stomach. Relieves congestion. Soothes the stomach lining. Helps stop hiccups. Soothes menstrual cramps and treats irritable bowel syndrome. Reduces pain and relaxes tight muscles. Leaves used in tea for migraine headache and stomach pain relief. Treats E. coli and Shigella bacterial infections. Tumor inhibitor. Radioprotective. Extracts have been shown to protect the liver and kidneys against chemical attack. Peppermint oil helps dissolve gallstones. Oil can also be used as a forehead compress for tension headache relief. Peppermint oil can help reduce vomiting and the frequency and severity of nausea in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. Peppermint oil can also be used to treat itching and pruritis in pregnant women. Gargle is used to treat sore throats. Stress reliever. Peppermint ointments have been used to treat infected wounds. Combinations of peppermint and spearmint tea with honey can soothe the nervous system. Peppermint and licorice blended tea is good for soothing a cough. Scents from menthol and peppermint have been used to promote wakefulness. Breath freshener. Water purifier. Peppermint oil can cause heartburn, and may be irritating to the skin in some sensitive individuals. Not recommended for patients with gallbladder inflammation, bile duct obstruction, or severe liver damage.

 

 

PERIWINKLE

Powerful cancer fighter. Treatment for circulatory disorders. Tropical periwinkle is the source for the anti-cancer drugs vinblastine and vincristine, which are used in the treatment of childhood leukemias and Hodgkin's disease. The lesser periwinkle is the source for vinpocetine, which has been used to treat dementia, ischemia, and tinnitus. Lowers blood sugar levels. Improves vascular insufficiency and blood microcirculation. It also boosts memory and learning. Side effects include skin flushing and stomachache. Use extreme caution when using this highly toxic herb.

 

 

PERSIMMON

High in antioxidants. Anti-inflammatory. Antiviral. Astringent. Treats seafood poisoning. Anti-tumor. Cancer cell inhibitor. Stops bloody bowels. Leaf extracts have been shown to significantly lower total serum cholesterol and triglycerides, and raise beneficial HDL levels. Leaf extracts can also prevent and treat gastric ulcers. Extracts also lower blood sugar levels in diabetics. High in fiber which helps increase elimination. Helpful for the obese. Treats infant's thrush caused by yeast infections. Helps remove intestinal parasites and worms. Extracts protect DNA and the liver against chemical poisonings. Extracts are neuroprotective. May be helpful in the treatment of arthritis and Alzheimers disease. Leaf compounds treat allergic contact dermatitis. Leaf extracts may be helpful in treatment and prevention of degenerative retinal diseases such as retinitis pigmentosa and age-related macular degeneration. Leaf extracts may also be helpful in treating atopic dermatitis. Juice is used for cleansing skin ulcers and wounds. Dried persimmon can help to lessen alcohol blood concentrations. With horehound, used to treat throbbing headaches from alcoholic hangovers.

 

 

PHYLLANTHUS

Indian herb provides support for the liver and has been shown to promote liver regeneration. Protects the liver against chemical attack. Treats viral infections, including hepatitis. Cancer cell and tumor inhibitor. Some species (e.g. P. amarus) have shown anti-malarial activity, and may be able to reduce the Plasmodium-induced kidney damage associated with infection.

 

 

 

PILCHARD

High in beneficial omega-3 fatty acids that help support the brain, nervous system, and prostate. Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, dementia, and Alzheimers disease. Anti-inflammatory. Lowers blood pressure and cholesterol. Rich source of Vitamin D which is essential for cell replication, calcium absorption and metabolism, normal insulin secretion, and bone health. Vitamin D also provides protection against bone diseases, many cancers, multiple sclerosis, diabetes, gum disease, and muscle problems. Rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Anti-inflammatory. May protect the heart against sudden attack. Fish oil may help maintain insulin levels in diabetics and improve breathing in asthma sufferers. Also treats acute respiratory distress syndrome, psoriasis, multiple sclerosis, and dysmennorrhea. Treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, but not recommended if you have gout.

 

 

 

PINE

Powerful antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Antiviral. Analgesic. Neuroprotective. Pine bark and oils have been used to treat acne, asthma, blood clots, bronchitis, edema, high cholesterol, diabetes, emphysema, fatigue, fever, fungal infections, gout, hepatitis, hypertension, influenza, leukemia, lupus, migraines, morning sickness, motion sickness, paralysis, Parkinson's disease, rheumatoid and osteoarthritis, scurvy, skin ulcers, sinusitis, stroke, and varicose veins. Bark extracts from French maritime pine (pycnogenol) have been used to treat bleeding gums, heal hemorrhoids, lower blood pressure, and reduce plaque. Pycnogenol may be also be helpful in treating the early stages of mild cognitive impairment. Bark extracts also treat erectile dysfunction in men. Extracts may also help children overcome attention deficit and hyperactivity disorders (ADHD). French maritime pine extracts have also been shown to lower blood pressure and cholesterol levels, lower blood sugar levels, relieve chronic venous insufficiency, improve photo-damaged skin, reduce age spots, protect the liver against chemical attack, treat allergic asthma, protect the lungs against tobacco smoke injury, and reduce the side effects of gynecological hormone therapies. French maritime pine bark bilberry fruit extracts may be helpful in treating glaucoma. Monterey pine extracts are helpful in slowing age-related cognitive decline. Pine nuts are high in protein and help lubricate the lungs and intestines. They can also be used with goat's milk as an excellent facial mask. High in arginine, an amino acid which has been shown to increase the bodys production of nitric oxide. Nitric oxide helps dilate blood vessels, lower blood pressure, and improve blood circulation to the heart, brain, and bladder. Arginine therapy has also been used to treat lead intoxication and reduce the parasite burden in the treatment of severe malaria and leishmaniasis. Aflatoxin inhibitor. Pine nuts are also high in Vitamin K which is essential in the production of blood clotting proteins, improves bone metabolism, and has been shown to have anti-cancer effects (e.g. Non-Hodgkins lymphoma). Extracts may be helpful in protecting against DNA damage. Pine needle extracts can help lower blood sugar levels and treat depression. Cancer cell inhibitor (e.g. breast). Pine needle and bark extracts are also natural tumor inhibitors. Pine needles offers protection against UV-induced sunlight damage, have shown promise in the treatment of metabolic bone diseases, and also in the treatment of stress-related memory impairment. Pine needles have also been used to monitor air pollution. Cosmetic products made from pine needle extracts have been used to reduce skin ageing and wrinkling. Ointments prepared from pine cone oils are effective wound healers. Pine nuts are used in pesto sauces. Pine nuts are high in fat, but most of it is unsaturated and has not been shown to be a major contributor to obesity if eaten in moderation. Nuts can provoke severe and even life-threatening reactions in allergically sensitive individuals.


 

 

PINEAPPLE

Antioxidant. Antiviral. Analgesic. Effective anti-inflammatory. High in Vitamin C which boosts the immune system, helps lower blood pressure, and has been used in the prevention and treatment of many cancers. High in potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure, promote a steady heartbeat, and lower your risk of stroke. Rich in enzymes that help metabolize foods and fend off allergies and autoimmune disorders. Rich source of iodine, which is necessary to produce thyroid hormone, which regulates the body's energy level, and is essential for fetal and childhood brain development. Blood thinner. Prevents clots and promotes circulation. Breaks down arteriosclerotic plaques and relieves heartburn. Good for sore throats. The enzyme bromelain, in cream form, helps speed up healing of bruises and sports-related injuries such as tendonitis in athletes. Inhibits tumors and heals ulcers. Treats rheumatoid arthritis. Shown to promote the healing of third degree burns. Bromelain also flushes fat from the body by stimulating metabolism and ridding the body of excess fluids. It is also used as a digestive enzyme replacement to ease pain and increase absorption of both natural and synthetic medicines. Bromelain is also nephroprotective and neuroprotective, and may be helpful in treating strokes. Bromelain has been used to treat sinus inflammation and soft tissue injuries such as carpel tunnel syndrome and plantar fasciitis. Bromelain has also been shown to treat postoperative edemas and intestinal blockages in dental and medical surgeries, respectively, and to reduce symptoms in colitis patients. Because bromelain reduces inflammation, it may also be helpful for asthma sufferers. Bromelain extracts from pineapple peels have been used as meat tenderizers. Bromelain is also a cancer cell inhibitor. Bromelain has shown an ability to protect the testes against toxic metal contamination. When mixed with curcumin (turmeric), used as a treatment for lupus. Peel extracts have mild anti-malarial properties, and may protect brain tissues from alcohol-related stress. Fruit can be used externally to remove warts and corns. An unpeeled fruit drink can been used to expel intestinal parasites. The boiled rind combined with rosemary treats skin rashes, eczema, dermatitis, psoriasis, jock itch, and hemorrhoids. Diluted juice treats nausea-induced motion sickness. Canned pineapple is used as a dip for athlete's foot and nail fungus. Leaf extracts can increase beneficial HDL cholesterol levels, lower blood sugar levels, and have shown promise in treating diabetes. Fruit extracts can promote wound healing. Pineapple juice contains high amounts of the neurotransmitter serotonin, which may help treat those with depression. Pineapple juice may also be helpful in improving memory in those with cognitive disorders. Leaves are also used topically to remove ringworm. Some individuals may be allergically sensitive to bromelain.

 

 

PINKROOT

Used in teas to expel intestinal parasites and worms. Stimulant. Extreme caution should be taken when using this highly toxic herb.

 

 

PION BLANCO

The sap of this Peruvian shrub is used as a painless wart removal treatment.

 

 

PIPSISSEWA

Treatment for urinary tract infections and cystitis. Antibacterial. Diaphoretic (induces sweating). Astringent. Diuretic. Used externally to heal blisters and swellings.

 

 

PISTACHIO

Antioxidant. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Anti-inflammatory. Rich in protein. Nuts are high in Vitamin B6 which is critical for protein and red blood cell metabolism, for the proper functioning of the nervous and immune systems, for the maintenance of blood sugar levels, and may be protective against some cancers (e.g. colorectal and lung). Kidney and liver tonic. Extracts can also protect the liver and kidneys against chemical attack. Shown to lower total serum cholesterol and triglycerides, lower harmful LDL, and raise beneficial HDL levels. Pistachio nuts are a good source of carotenoids such as lutein which accumulate in the retina. Luteins improve visual function and can help prevent eye diseases such as age-related cataracts and macular degeneration. Pistachios help lubricate the intestines. Extracts have been used in mouth rinses to reduce dental plaque. Tumor and cancer cell inhibitor. Lowers blood sugar levels. Used in combination with peanut oil as a massage oil. Extracts may be helpful in treating the joint stiffness and pain of osteoarthritis. High in arginine, an amino acid which has been shown to increase the bodys production of nitric oxide. Nitric oxide helps dilate blood vessels, lower blood pressure, and improve blood circulation to the heart, brain, and bladder. Arginine therapy has also been used to treat lead intoxication and reduce the parasite burden in the treatment of severe malaria and leishmaniasis. Pistachio skin extracts can be used topically to protect the skin against UV-induced sunlight damage. Nuts, in general, are high in fat, but most of it is unsaturated and has not been shown to be a major contributor to obesity if eaten in moderation. Nuts can provoke severe and even life-threatening reactions in allergically sensitive individuals.

 

 

PLANTAIN

Antioxidant. Antibacterial. Antiviral. Antifungal. Analgesic. Natural antibiotic. Anti-inflammatory. Immune system booster. Stem extracts can protect the liver against chemical attack. Lowers blood sugar and cholesterol. Cancer cell and tumor inhibitor. Used in cancer treatments. Contains allantoin, a proven skin and wound healer that promotes the growth of connective tissue. Allantoin may also be helpful in the treatment of hypertension. Leaves help soothe an irritated respiratory tract. Neuroprotective. Stem extracts are anticonvulsant, and may be helpful for those with epilepsy. Relieves peptic and gastric ulcers. Helps reduce kidney stones and bladder pain. Stops tooth pain. Unripened fruit extracts have shown hair growth potential. Tea helps treat anxiety and insomnia. Plantain syrup may be helpful in reducing symptoms of radiation-induced mucositis in head and neck cancer patients. Seed extracts help increase exercise endurance. Crushed leaves can be used as a poultice for treating insect bites, stings, and poison ivy rashes. Broadleaf plantain seeds treat ulcerative colitis. Heals wounds, treats pressure ulcers, and is also used as a hemostat to stop bleeding. Plantain syrup may be helpful for women who are experiencing heavy menstrual bleeding. Effective laxative if taken internally. Green plantain can be effective in the treatment of persistent diarrhea in children. Asian plantain extracts may be helpful in the treatment of gout.

 

 

PLEURISY ROOT

SEE: BUTTERFLY WEED

 

 

PLUM

Antioxidant. Antiviral. Anti-inflammatory. High in potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure, promote a steady heartbeat, and lower your risk of stroke. Prunes also lower total and LDL blood cholesterol levels. Bark extracts treat testosterone-induced benign prostatic hyperplasia. Treats cold or canker sores. Plum seed kernels are antifungal and insecticidal. Umeboshi plums can be used to treat gastrointestinal amoebas. Prunes (dried plums) are very high in antioxidants. Prunes can lower blood pressure and are also very high in fiber which helps increase elimination. Anti-ulcer. Prunes may also be helpful in preventing bone loss in postmenopausal women. Both prunes and prune juice are outstanding laxatives. Extracts can protect the liver against chemical attack. Prune fruit extracts may be helpful in improving the healing of wounds.

 

 

 

POI

SEE: TARO


 

 

POKEWEED

High in Vitamin A which helps form and maintain teeth, tissues, and skin. Vitamin A also produces pigments that are essential for good vision. Tea treats glandular inflammations including tonsillitis, swollen lymph nodes, mastitis, and breast cancer. Used in herbal washes and in ointment form to treat skin maladies such as chickenpox, measles, mumps, herpes, shingles, psoriasis, eczema, scabies, ringworm, skin ulcers, fungal infections, boils, carbuncles, bedsores, and rashes. Pokeweed has been shown to kill the freshwater snails that host the flatworms that infect humans causing schistosomiasis.

 

POLLOCK

Good protein source. Lowers blood sugar levels and improves insulin sensitivity. Consumption of Alaskan pollock has been shown to be protective against nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.

 

 

POMEGRANATE

Pomegranate juices, peels, wines, and oils are very rich in antioxidants. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Antiviral. Anti-inflammatory. Astringent. Analgesic. Good source of Vitamin C which boosts the immune system, helps lower blood pressure, and has been used in the prevention and treatment of many cancers. Dried seeds are one of the best treatments for removing intestinal parasites and worms, especially tapeworms. Fruits and peels are used to treat diarrhea. Treats intestinal bowel diseases. Ulcer, tumor, and cancer cell inhibitor (e.g. liver, oral, prostate). Shown to inhibit and shrink tumors in those with prostate cancer. Pomegranate juice also reduces blood pressure, lowers total and LDL blood cholesterol levels, and may slow the progression of dementia and Alzheimers disease. May be helpful in preventing and treating nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Helps reduce the size of atherosclerotic plaques. Heart protector and tonic. Treats myocardial ischemia and infarctions. Colon, lung, breast, and skin cancer preventative. May be helpful in the treatment of leukemia. Peels are rich in ellagic acid, which is thought to be responsible for the anti-cancer effect. Ellagic acid, a neuroprotective and gastroprotective compound, has also shown some anti-malarial and anti-epileptic properties. Ellagic acid may also be helpful in promoting hair growth in testosterone-induced alopecia. Floral, peel, and juice extracts lower blood sugar levels and have been used in the treatment of diabetes. Protects the kidneys against chemical attack. Treats painful diabetic neuropathy, diabetic nephropathy, rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, and ulcerative colitis. Peel extracts may be helpful in the treatment of autoimmune disorders such as multiple sclerosis. Extracts have been shown to protect the liver, brain, and other organs against chemical poisoning. Pomegranate consumption may help to enhance cognitive and functional recovery after a stroke. Helpful for the obese because it reduces inflammatory symptoms. Some pomegranate wines contain melatonin which is an excellent treatment for insomnia. Pomegranate is a potent source of estrogens that treat bone loss in those suffering from osteopenia (and in menopausal women), treats anxiety and depression, and may be an effective breast cancer cell inhibitor and preventative. Antihistamine. Floral bud extracts may be helpful in the treatment of asthma. Peel extracts may be helpful in treating Giardia infections. Extracts have shown promise in the treatment of insect-vectored diseases such as leishmaniasis. Pomegranate juice may be helpful in the treatment of multiple myeloma. Pomegranate extracts are neuroprotective, and may be protective against cerebral ischemia. Extracts may also help reduce stress associated with sleep deprivation. Peel and floral extracts can be used topically in ointments and creams for treating wounds and healing burns. Peels have also been used to treat malarial infections by reducing inflammation, parasite load, and spleen injury caused by parasitic activity. Pomegranate rind treats diarrhea. Peel extracts may be helpful in treating skin hyperpigmentation. Extracts offer protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Extracts may also be protective against ionizing radiation such as medical X-rays. Juice consumption is helpful for hemodialysis patients, and has been shown to inhibit the HIV virus. Juice may also improve sperm quality in men. Treats E. coli bacterial infections. Fruit extracts have been used in mouth-rinses, and to help reduce dental plaque and periodontal disease. Extracts may be helpful in treating pica, an eating disorder characterized by a craving for non-food items such as dirt and paper.

 

 

POMELO

Antioxidant. Hepatoprotective. Helpful for diabetics. Peel extracts can lower blood sugar, cholesterol, and triglyceride levels.

 

 

 

POPLAR

Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Treats topically skin afflictions such as acne, skin ulcers, gangrenous wounds, eczema, burns, warts, and body odor. Used internally for pain relief and rheumatism.

 

 

 

POPPY

Source for powerful analgesics and sedatives such as opium, codeine, morphine, and heroin. Seeds are high in magnesium, which is a natural tranquilizer and helps the body to regulate cholesterol and blood sugar levels. Magnesium is also good for relief of migraines and helps slow bone loss. Seeds are also a good calcium source. Calcium helps form and preserve teeth and bones and prevent osteoporosis. Seed oil is used in soaps, paints, and varnishes. The leaves of some species (e.g. Mexican poppy) have been used to treat and heal wounds.

 

 

PORK

Great protein source. High in folic acid (Vitamin B9) and selenium. Folic acid is essential for DNA synthesis and repair, and has been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, fetal neural tube defects, cervical dysplasia, heart disease, bowel problems, and certain cancers (e.g. oral, pharyngeal, bladder, colorectal, and pancreas). Selenium is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Pig fat (lard) has been used externally to promote hair growth. Cured ham and bacon are high in sodium which can be a major contributor to hypertension in salt-sensitive individuals. Bacon is also high in saturated fat which can contribute to atherosclerosis. High salt diets can also deplete the bodys calcium levels, which can increase the risk of developing osteoporosis.

 

 

 

POTATO

Cooked russet potatoes are very high in antioxidants. Anti-inflammatory. Rich in Vitamin C which boosts the immune system, helps lower blood pressure, and has been used in the prevention and treatment of many cancers. High in potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure, promote a steady heartbeat, and lower your risk of stroke. Lowers cholesterol and triglyceride levels, and helps reduce heart disease. Potatoes are also a source of carotenoids such as lutein and zeaxanthin which accumulate in the retina. Luteins improve visual function and can help prevent eye diseases such as age-related cataracts and macular degeneration. Intestinal cleaner. Increases stool weight and movements (with unpeeled spuds). Non-fattening (used in weight loss programs). Skin contains beneficial antioxidants. Peelings have been used in broths to expel gallstones. Potato peels contain compounds that may be helpful in treating pathogenic protozoan diseases. Possible suicide preventative. Potato juice can inhibit gastric ulcer formation. Used as a plaster to reduce inflammations and for drawing out purulent matter from skin eruptions, cysts, and tumors. Extracts may be helpful in the treatment of chronic arthritis and rheumatism. The addition of raw potato starch to pan-fried meats has been shown to reduce the formation of heterocyclic amines which are considered to be carcinogenic substances produced by the cooking process. Sweet potatoes lower blood sugar levels and help stimulate the immune system. Sweet potatoes are also high in fiber and rich in beta-carotene and Vitamin A. Beta-carotene can help prevent the development of eye diseases such as cataracts and macular degeneration. Beta-carotene also offers protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Vitamin A helps form and maintain teeth, tissues, and skin. Vitamin A also produces pigments that are essential for good vision. Fiber helps increase elimination. Helpful for the obese. Sweet potato extracts are neuroprotective and anti-tumor, and can inhibit cancer cell growth. Sweet potato tubers help treat peptic ulcers. Sweet potatoes also help prevent high-fat diet-induced aortic stiffness. Purple-fleshed sweet potatoes are high in anthocyanins which may lower ones risk for colon cancer. Anthocyanins may also offer protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Potato peel extracts can protect the liver and kidneys against chemical attack. Yam peel extracts are antifungal. Yams provide support for the liver and gallbladder. Yams are rich in allantoin, a proven skin and wound healer that promotes the growth of connective tissue. Allantoin may also be helpful in the treatment of hypertension. Yams also help remove heavy metals from the body such as cadmium, copper, mercury, and lead (sulphur-rich). Consuming yams and sweet potatoes may be protective in cities with high smog rates. These potatoes are also used to facilitate removal of foreign objects swallowed accidentally by coating the object till it is expelled later on. Potato skins have also been used to remove warts. Boiled potato peels have been used as dressings to treat burn victims. Sweet potato tuber peels have also been used to treat and heal wounds. Sweet potato purees may positively effect gut microbiota by promoting the growth of beneficial bacteria such as Bifidobacterium. Leaves, sprouts, vines, fruits, and green tubers are considered poisonous and should not be consumed. Keep in mind that some members of the nightshade family, which includes tomatoes, eggplants, peppers, and potatoes, have been known to provoke allergic and other adverse reactions in some sensitive individuals when consumed in sufficient quantities. Potato skins often contain high concentrations of pesticides; to reduce your intake of residues, be sure to peel, wash, and thoroughly cook potatoes before consumption.



 

POTENTILLA

SEE: CINQUEFOIL

 

PRAWN

SEE: SHRIMP

 

 

PRICKLY ASH

Antifungal. Tones and stimulates the lymphatic system. Restores salivary gland functions and taste. Treats rheumatism, muscle paralysis, arthritis, peritonitis, bowel distention, abdominal inflammations, and swelling. Promotes intense fever relief from cholera, typhus, typhoid, and pneumonia. Lowers blood pressure. Diaphoretic. Increases the body's ability to sweat out toxins. Possible remedy for sickle-cell anemia. Poultice used for muscle and joint pain relief. Bark used in tooth powders and for toothache. Twigs are used as a toothbrush for cleaning teeth and gums.

SEE ALSO: ASH

 

PRICKLY PEAR

SEE: CACTUS

 

PRIVET

SEE: LIGUSTRUM

 

 

PROBIOTICS

SEE: YOGURT

 

PROPOLIS

Propolis is a wax or resin collected by bees from flower buds that is used as a hive sealant (bee glue). Rich in antioxidants. Antiprotozoal. Antiviral. Antifungal. Antibacterial. Antiseptic. Anti-inflammatory. Analgesic. Propolis has broad-spectrum anti-viral activity, and, as such, may be helpful in treating or preventing viruses including COVID-19. Laxative. Treats ulcers. Protects the liver, kidneys, and reproductive organs against chemical attack. Extracts are also protective against alcohol-induced gastric lesions, and may be helpful in the treatment of colitis and inflammatory bowel disease. Cardioprotective. Chrysin, a phytoestrogen found in honey and propolis, is protective against benign prostatic hyperplasia, and can also protect the testis against chemical attack. Lowers blood pressure, cholesterol, and blood sugar levels. Treats metabolic syndrome and diabetic nephropathy. Helpful for diabetics and the obese. Boosts the immune system. Treats depression, stress, and anxiety. Extracts may be helpful in treating cognitive functions such as memory in the elderly. Some varieties of propolis have neuroprotective properties, and have shown some promise in the treatment of insect-vectored diseases such as leishmaniasis, schistosomiasis, and trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease). Propolis can help inhibit intestinal parasites such as the protozoan, Giardia, which can be present in contaminated food and water. Shown to inhibit the growth of tumors. Protects cells against radiation damage. Treatment for trichomoniasis, a common sexually transmitted disease in women. Helps protect against male infertility. May also help increase sperm production in men. Propolis extracts have been used to stimulate hair growth. Used to increase the effectiveness of natural or synthetic antibiotics. Possible HIV suppresser. Gastroprotective. Cancer cell inhibitor (e.g. gastric) and preventative. Treatment for kidney cancer. May also be helpful in treating leukemia. When used before treatment, can reduce symptoms of radiation sickness. Oral antiseptic. Used in some toothpastes. May be helpful in the treatment of acne, oral thrush, gingivitis, dental caries, periodontal disease, and denture stomatitis. Extracts have been shown to offer protection against UV sunlight damage. Wound cleaner and healer. Used topically to improve healing in those with diabetic foot ulcers. Ointment treats minor burns, abrasions, swellings, venous ulcers, and herpes skin lesions. Also treats warts, athletes foot, and vaginal yeast infections.

 

 

PRUNE

SEE: PLUM

 

 

PSYLLIUM

Psyllium seed is a bulk-forming laxative, and is one of the best colon cleaners. Use 100% for extra fiber to help increase elimination. Treats constipation, diarrhea, irritable bowel syndrome, ulcerative colitis, and hemorrhoids. Removes intestinal toxins. Reduces blood sugar levels in diabetics. Lowers blood pressure. Seed husks may be helpful in reducing coronary artery damage due to myocardial infarction. Increases feelings of fullness after a meal (helpful for the obese). Excellent at lowering LDL, total cholesterol, and triglyceride levels. Shown to increase beneficial HDL cholesterol levels. Possible colon cancer preventative. Be sure to take psyllium with plenty of water to prevent intestinal obstruction. Short-term symptoms include flatulence, bloating, and mild abdominal discomfort. Some people are allergically sensitive to psyllium. Not recommended for those with bowel obstruction disorders.

 

 

PUMPKIN

Fruit extracts of some varieties are antifungal and are aflatoxin inhibitors. Pumpkin is rich in Vitamin A which helps form and maintain teeth, tissues, and skin. Vitamin A also produces pigments that are essential for good vision. Also high in Vitamin K, which is essential in the production of blood clotting proteins, improves bone metabolism, and has been shown to have anti-cancer effects (e.g. Non-Hodgkins lymphoma). Seeds are rich in protein and are used as a treatment for edema, gout, inflammation, nausea, bladder and kidney stones, and urinary problems. Pumpkin seed oil lowers blood pressure, is cardioprotective, and may also be helpful in treating male pattern baldness. Pumpkin leaf extracts or oil may also be helpful in preventing acetaminophen or alcohol-induced liver disease. Both pumpkin and squash seeds are also rich in zinc, which is vital for a healthy immune system, skin repair injuries, the digestion of starchy food, thyroid hormone metabolism, and regulation of the prostate gland. Pumpkin seeds and seed oil, respectively, treats benign prostatic hyperplasia and male erectile dysfunction. Helps prevents the breakdown of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. Seeds or fresh flesh can be used to eliminate parasites such as tapeworms, roundworms, and pinworms from the body. Seeds have also been used in treatment programs for anxiety, depression, and sleep disorders. Cancer preventative. Squash and its seeds are high in antioxidants. Pumpkin and Italian squash are rich in beta-carotene. Beta-carotene can help prevent the development of eye diseases such as cataracts and macular degeneration. Beta-carotene also offers protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Butternut squash is very high in Vitamin C, calcium, and beta-carotene. Vitamin C boosts the immune system, helps lower blood pressure, and has been used in the prevention and treatment of many cancers. Acorn squash is also a good source of calcium. Calcium helps form and preserve teeth and bones and prevent osteoporosis. Winter squash is high in potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure, promote a steady heartbeat, and lower your risk of stroke. Yellow squash is high in carotenoids which can help prevent the development of eye diseases such as cataracts and macular degeneration. Mashed pumpkin has been used as a poultice for burns and inflammation relief. Pumpkin powder or seed flour lowers blood sugar and cholesterol. Some squash varieties are anti-inflammatory. Squash extracts (e.g. winter squash) also lower blood sugar levels, and may be helpful for diabetics. Pulp compresses treat migraines, earaches, and burns. Pumpkin oil or paste treats burns, scratches, and wounds. Leaves can be used as a poultice for sprains, fractures, tendonitis, and backache. Leaf tea helps reduce fevers and stop diarrhea.

 

 

PURSLANE

Rich in antioxidants. Anti-inflammatory. Antibacterial. Analgesic. Diuretic. Rich in Vitamins A and C. Vitamin A helps form and maintain teeth, tissues, and skin. Vitamin A also produces pigments that are essential for good vision. Vitamin C boosts the immune system, helps lower blood pressure, and has been used in the prevention and treatment of many cancers. High in beneficial omega-3 fatty acids that help support the brain, nervous system, and prostate. Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, dementia, and Alzheimers disease. Lowers blood pressure and blood sugar levels. Also lowers triglycerides and total cholesterol levels. Liver cancer inhibitor. Protects the liver against chemical attack. Kidney and pancreas protector. Treatment for diabetic nephropathy. Treats respiratory problems such as asthma and bronchitis, urinary tract disorders, and skin afflictions. Also treats arthritis, inflammatory bowel diseases, and gastrointestinal problems. Purslane extracts have shown promise in the treatment of leishmaniasis. Protects against alcohol-induced gastric lesions. Induces heart contractions in those with low blood pressure. Used topically to accelerate wound healing. Purslane cream has been used to promote the healing of nipple fissures in lactating women. Fatigue fighter. Helps lower exercise-induced stress. Anxiety reliever. Treats oral lichen planus. Extracts are neuroprotective and have shown the ability to protect nervous tissue and the brain from mercury-induced neurotoxicity and hypoxia (oxygen deprivation). Seed extracts may also be helpful in treating Parkinsons disease. Seeds have been used to treat abnormal uterine bleeding.

 

 

PUSSY WILLOW

SEE: CATTAIL

 

 

PYGEUM

African plum tree helps protect the prostate gland. Treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia and chronic prostatitis. Prevents the breakdown of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. Also treats urinary problems.




 

Q

 

 

 

 

QUASSIA

Digestive aid. Appetite stimulant. Increases gastric juices. Ulcer inhibitor. Lowers blood sugar levels in diabetics. In larger doses, can help expel intestinal parasites such as amoebas and the protozoan, Giardia, which can be present in contaminated food and water. Caribbeans have used this herb in teas to treat malaria and dysentery. Quassia extracts have also shown promise in the treatment of leishmaniasis. Quassin, extracted from the quassia tree, is the bitterest substance known to exist naturally.

 

 

QUEEN ANNES LACE

Possible contraceptive. Root extracts may be helpful in treating urolithiasis. Seeds are thought to block the production of progesterone, which is necessary for proper fertilization in women.

 

 

QUINCE

Antioxidant. Antibacterial. Anti-inflammatory. Anti-allergy. Lowers blood sugar levels. Leaf extracts help lower blood pressure. Lowers total cholesterol, LDL levels, and triglycerides, and increases beneficial HDL cholesterol levels. Colon cancer cell and ulcer inhibitor. Treats ulcerative colitis. Helpful for the obese. Protects the liver and kidneys against chemical attack. Male aphrodisiac. Used in facial masks to improve complexion. Creams made from seeds extracts have been used as moisturizers and to accelerate wound healing.

 

 

QUININE

Used as a bitter flavoring agent in tonic water. Bark extracts treat malarial fevers and infections. Berry skin is used by Australian aborigines as a male contraceptive. Treats painful leg cramps. Exercise caution when using quinine, since some people have experienced toxic side effects including anemia, rashes, and vision problems.

 

 

QUINOA

Antioxidant. Highly nutritious protein-rich grain (technically a seed). High in fiber which helps increase elimination. Treats liver and urinary disorders and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Lowers blood pressure and cholesterol levels. Promotes oxygenation of the blood. Helpful for the obese.




 

R

 

 

 

 

RADISH

Antioxidant. Antibacterial. Seeds are anti-inflammatory and are cancer cell inhibitors. Radish greens are a good source of beta-carotene. Beta-carotene can help prevent the development of eye diseases such as cataracts and macular degeneration. Beta-carotene also offers protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Cancer cell inhibitor (e.g. breast, colon). Can protect against breast and colon cancer. Seeds in tea have been used to reduce stomach cancer. Juice treats abdominal cancers. Provides detoxification support for the stomach, liver, and gallbladder. Helps in the digestion of starches. A drink made with carrots helps to remove fatty deposits in tissues. Boiled roots have been used to relieve symptoms of chronic coughing and raging fevers. Combined with milk, helps treat diarrhea. Combined with wine, helps to prevent gall and kidney stones. Radish sprouts are rich in anthocyanins which may lower ones risk for colon cancer. Leaf extracts treat gastric ulcers and can help lower blood pressure. Root juice can lower blood sugar levels. Extracts can lower triglyceride levels. Radish juice or seed extracts can protect the liver against chemical attack. Neuroprotective. Radish extracts may be helpful in treating memory and learning impairment in those with Alzheimers disease. Radish juice also has been used as a deodorant for feet and underarms. Radishes have been used in bioremediation programs to help remove contaminants from polluted water. Poultices treat external burns and scalds. When heated, the poultice has also been used to treat breast cancer.

 

 

RAISIN

SEE: GRAPES

 

 

RAPESEED

Also called canola. Oil is high in beneficial omega-3 fatty acids, which support the heart, nervous system, and prostate. Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, dementia, and Alzheimers disease. Canola oil is high in Vitamin K, which is essential in the production of blood clotting proteins, improves bone metabolism, and has been shown to have anti-cancer effects (e.g. Non-Hodgkins lymphoma). Rapeseed oil can lower total and LDL cholesterol levels. May be protective against nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Tumor inhibitor. Rapeseed protein is used primarily as a feed grain. Some studies have suggested that regular consumption of rapeseed oil may contribute to an increase in blood pressure and hypertension, especially in salt-sensitive individuals.

 

 

RASPBERRY

High in antioxidants. Antiviral. Antifungal. Antibacterial. Anti-inflammatory. Anti-aging. Immune system stimulant. Contains natural salicylates (aspirin). Provides common cold relief. Major tumor and cancer cell inhibitor (e.g. lung). Red raspberries are the richest known source of ellagic acid, which is thought to be responsible for the anti-cancer effect. Ellagic acid, a neuroprotective and gastroprotective compound, has also shown some anti-malarial and anti-epileptic properties. Ellagic acid may also be helpful in promoting hair growth in testosterone-induced alopecia. Diuretic. Lowers blood sugar and promotes insulin production. Raspberries contain xylitol, a naturally occurring sugar alcohol, that has been shown to reduce dental caries. Raspberries are also rich in anthocyanins which may lower ones risk for colon cancer. Anthocyanins may also offer protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Contains linoleic acid that helps skin look healthier and younger. The linoleic acid in black raspberry seed oil can also help lower triglyceride levels. Extracts can inhibit DNA damage, and are neuroprotective. Helpful for the obese. Lowers blood pressure. Protects the liver against chemical attack. May be helpful in the treatment of ulcerative colitis. Treats arthritis. High in calcium and minerals. Calcium helps form and preserve teeth and bones and prevent osteoporosis. Helpful for all female organs and problems. Leaf tea is used by midwives to strengthen the muscles of the uterus prior to pregnancy. Promotes shorter and easier labor. Helps decrease menstrual flow and cramps. Black raspberries may be helpful in preventing endometrial cancer. Black raspberry fruit extracts help treat chronic muscle pain. Memory enhancer. Tea excellent for morning sickness, nausea, diarrhea, and a pain-free pregnancy and childbirth. Used as a mouthwash and gargle for infections. Helps prevent tartar buildup on teeth. Used to treat muscular paralysis due to electric shock, hypertension, and skin cancer. May be helpful in the treatment of severe allergic reactions such as anaphylaxis. Raspberries are also a good fiber source, which helps increase elimination.

 

 

RED CLOVER

Antifungal. Antispasmodic. Expectorant. Anti-inflammatory. Treatment for diarrhea. Tea treats a sore throat and whooping cough. Blood purifier and cleanser. Relieves heart pain and phlebitis. Can reduce the growth of cancerous tumors and associated intense pain. Contains estrogenic compounds (e.g. isoflavones) which can increase estrogen levels. Red clover is a good source of these isoflavones, which also offers protection against UV-induced sunlight damage (are anti-aging). Genistein, a naturally occurring anti-inflammatory, neuroprotective, and radioprotective compound found in soy and red clover, has been shown to inhibit liver infection by malarial parasites. Genistein can protect the liver against chemical attack. Genistein is also a cancer cell inhibitor. Improves arterial blood flow. Lowers blood sugar levels. Shown to significantly lower total serum cholesterol and triglycerides, lower harmful LDL, and raise beneficial HDL levels. Reduces bone loss in menopausal women. Decreases the incidence and severity of hot flashes. Reduces blood clots and abdominal cramps. Helps clear the body of toxins. Treats indigestion. Tones and stimulates the lymphatic system. Antiseptic. Good for acne and skin problems such as eczema, burns, ulcers, and psoriasis.

 

 

RED PEPPER

SEE: CAYENNE

 

 

RED ROOT

Tones and stimulates the lymphatic system.

 

 

REHMANNIA

Anti-inflammatory. Adrenal glands system builder. Lowers blood sugar in diabetics. Kidney protector.

 

 

 

RHODIOLA

Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Neuroprotective. Antiviral. Treats influenza, fatigue, physical exhaustion, anxiety, stress, depression, anger, confusion, insomnia, and schizophrenia. Protects the heart. Helps enhance physical and mental performance for those individuals who suffer from acute or chronic overwork, or who endure high levels of alternate stressors. Improves learning and memory. May be helpful in the treatment of Alzheimers disease. Extracts are radioprotective. Offers a protective effect against irradiation, extreme temperatures, oxygen deprivation, high-altitude illness, and intense physical activity or exercise. Lowers blood sugar levels. Helpful for diabetics. Extracts have been used to treat hypertension. Shown to significantly lower total serum cholesterol and triglycerides, lower harmful LDL, and raise beneficial HDL levels. May be helpful in the treatment of seasonal affective disorder, chronic fatigue, depression, and fibromyalgia. Tumor and cancer cell inhibitor. Treatment for breast cancer. Protects blood cells, the brain, and the liver against chemical poisonings. Tonic herb similar to ginseng in its effects. Regular use may cause an increase in irritability or insomnia.

 

 

 

RHODODENDRUM

Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Analgesic. Tea treats chronic cystitis. Remedy for kidney stones and provides kidney support. Helps reduce mucous congestion. Treatment for septic shock. Cancer cell inhibitor. Treatment for diarrhea. Leaf and floral extracts protect the liver against chemical attack. Floral extracts can also lower blood sugar levels, and may be protective against cerebral ischemia and myocardial injury. All raw plant parts are highly toxic and should not be consumed. Tea consumption is not recommended for long-term use.

 

 

RHUBARB

Antioxidant. Antibacterial. Antiviral. Anti-inflammatory. Anti-allergy. Laxative and astringent. Good calcium source. Lowers cholesterol and blood sugar levels. Treats inflammation of the pancreas and gallbladder. Tonic for the kidneys. Liver protector. Cancer cell inhibitor. Reduces tumors and melanomas. Rhubarb is high in athraquinones, compounds which have neuroprotective and anti-cancer properties. Extracts offer protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Helps relieve symptoms of psoriasis, arthritis, eczema, atopic dermatitis, herpes, acne, and hepatitis. Extracts may be helpful in the treatment of memory deficits and Alzheimers disease. May be helpful in treating intracerebral hemorrhage. Helps treat PMS and symptoms of menopause such as hot flashes and dysmenorrhea. Heals duodenal ulcers associated with digestive tract bleeding and aids recovery. Controls constipation and severe diarrhea. Juice strengthens tooth enamel. Remedy for cholera. Rhubarb may be helpful in the treatment of acute organophosphate pesticide poisoning. The leaves of this plant are poisonous and should not be consumed. Not recommended for pregnant women or for long-term use.

 

 

RICE

Good protein and antioxidant source. Anti-inflammatory. Reduces blood sugar. Prevents constipation and increases bowels. Rice bran is a powerful antioxidant that helps keep skin smooth and cements fractures. Enriched white rice is high in Vitamin B6 which is critical for protein and red blood cell metabolism, for the proper functioning of the nervous and immune systems, for the maintenance of blood sugar levels, and may be protective against some cancers (e.g. colorectal and lung). Can be eaten by those who are gluten intolerant (who have celiac disease). Rice is easily digested and rarely associated with any food allergy response. Cooked rice is helpful for the obese. Rice is high in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). White rice is rich in folic acid (Vitamin B9) which is essential for DNA synthesis and repair, and has been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, fetal neural tube defects, cervical dysplasia, heart disease, bowel problems, and certain cancers (e.g. oral, pharyngeal, bladder, colorectal, and pancreas). Good source of iron, which vitalizes blood cells and keeps your immune system healthy. Rice water and flour are used to treat diarrhea. Cooked rice can lower cholesterol levels. Rice bran can lower blood pressure, cholesterol, and blood sugar levels. Rice bran extracts are also natural antihistamines. Rice coffee and tea help relieve headaches produced by alcoholic hangovers. Rice wine, made from the fermented starch, is rich in antioxidants. Chinese red yeast rice lowers blood pressure, reduces total cholesterol and triglycerides, lowers harmful LDL while increasing beneficial HDL cholesterol levels, and promotes bone formation. Red yeast rice has also been shown to treat non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and prevent chronic alcohol-induced liver disease. Black rice extracts may be helpful in the treatment of asthma. Rice hull extracts may be helpful in treating benign prostatic hyperplasia. Rice bran is a good cancer preventative. Rice bran may be protective against alcoholic liver disease. Fermented rice bran may be helpful for the obese. Both rice bran and some rice varieties have shown an ability to inhibit the growth of tumor cells. Rice bran wax can be used as a skin moisturizer. Rice bran has also been used in the treatment of wastewater because it effectively removes some pesticides and other harmful organic compounds such as chloroform, toluene, and benzene. Side effects from consuming red yeast rice include headache and stomachache.

 

 

 

ROSE

Antioxidant. Antimicrobial. Anti-inflammatory. Rose petals are antibacterial. Rose hips (the seed pods) are among the richest known sources of Vitamin C, and are often used in supplements. Vitamin C boosts the immune system, helps lower blood pressure, and has been used in the prevention and treatment of many cancers. Rose hips are anti-inflammatory and have analgesic properties. They also contain lycopene, a potent antioxidant, which has been found to be protective against heart disease, cataracts, diabetes, and numerous cancers including skin, colorectal, gastric, lung, breast, pancreatic, ovarian, cervical, prostate, liver, and bladder. Lycopene can also protect the liver and kidneys against radiation damage and chemical attack. Lycopene is also an ulcer and tumor inhibitor, and is protective against gastroesophageal reflex disease. Higher serum lycopene levels can also reduce the risk of stroke and mortality from metabolic syndrome. Lycopene may be helpful in treating infertile men who have a low sperm count. Lycopene is also neuroprotective, and may protect against age-associated memory loss and cognitive defects. Rose hips and seed powder treat rheumatoid and osteoarthritis, protect cartilage, and help relieve chronic low back pain. Rose hips also help reduce the appearance of varicose veins. Rose hips are also a good source of folic acid which is essential for DNA synthesis and repair, and has been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, fetal neural tube defects, cervical dysplasia, heart disease, bowel problems, and certain cancers (e.g. oral, pharyngeal, bladder, colorectal, and pancreas). Rose hip extracts may be helpful in treating prediabetes, a condition of impaired glucose tolerance, but with normal blood glucose levels. Some rose hybrid oils (e.g. Damask rose), may be helpful in protect the testes and increasing the sperm count in males. Rose petals have been used to treat eating disorders such as anorexia and bulimia. Rose flavenoids can protect the liver against chemical attack. Rose extracts are cancer cell inhibitors. Extracts from some rose species (e.g. Rosa multiflora) may be protective against UV-induced skin photoaging. Rose extracts may also help to alleviate exercise-induced stress. Teas made from rose petals are high in antioxidants. Flowers from some rose species are anti-ulcer. Leafy pulp can be used as a poultice to promote the healing of external wounds. Root extracts may be helpful in stimulating hair growth as well as preventing hair loss. Rose oil may be helpful in treating gastroesophageal reflux disease. Rose extracts and rose oil exposure can help treat sleep deprivation and relieve stress and anxiety. Rose hip oil can promote the healing of wounds and help improve scars. Rose water is an excellent skin and facial cleanser. Rose petal extracts have been used as skin-whitening agents. It helps reduce skin wrinkling, reduces blackheads and acne, and can be used as an effective eyewash. Rose water can also be used as a treatment for bowel problems. Rose oil aromatherapy may provide pain relief for those with dysmenorrhea, and has also been used to help improve sleep quality in hospitalized patients.

 

 

ROSELLE

SEE: HIBISCUS

 

 

ROSEMARY

Contains natural salicylates (aspirin). Analgesic. Anti-inflammatory. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Antiviral. High in antioxidants and calcium. Calcium helps form and preserve teeth and bones and prevent osteoporosis. High in Vitamin B6 which is critical for protein and red blood cell metabolism, for the proper functioning of the nervous and immune systems, for the maintenance of blood sugar levels, and may be protective against some cancers (e.g. colorectal and lung). Lowers blood sugar levels. Prevents cellular DNA damage. Protects cells against radiation. Aflatoxin inhibitor. The addition of rosemary to pan-fried meats has been shown to reduce the formation of heterocyclic amines which are considered to be carcinogenic substances produced by the cooking process. Extracts can protect the liver and kidneys against chemical poisonings. Leaf extracts may be helpful in the treatment of trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease). Leaf extracts also treat neuropathic pain. Cancer cell and tumor inhibitor (e.g. colon). Protects lungs. Contains rosmarinic acid, an anti-inflammatory and neuroprotective compound that helps lower blood pressure and blood sugar levels, and treats symptoms of allergic rhinitis. Helpful for diabetics. Rosmarinic acid also treats diabetic neuropathy, and can protect the kidneys against chemical attack. Rosmarinic acid may also be helpful in treating acute pancreatitis, and as a cancer preventative. Rosmarinic acid has been shown to promote the regeneration of liver tissue. Rosmarinic acid can protect against chronic alcohol-induced memory and learning deficits, and may also help protect the spinal cord after injury. Rosmarinic acid may also be helpful in reducing blood pressure in those with hypertension. Helpful for the obese. Gastroprotective. Soothes the digestive system. Lowers triglycerides, LDL, and total cholesterol, and increases beneficial HDL cholesterol levels. Treats anxiety, depression, stress, rheumatism, gout, gastritis, stomach ulcers, colitis, and kidney stones. Improves sleep quality. Stimulates appetite. Neuroprotective. Extracts have been used to treat seizures and convulsions. May help restore brain function and memory in those with Alzheimer's disease. The inhalation of rosemary oil may be helpful in treating stress-related psychiatric disorders. Rosemary aroma can also help decrease sleepiness and increase alertness in shift workers. Helps liver by increasing bile flow. Relieves headaches. Water purifier. Strong diuretic. Used as a mouthwash for bad breath. Oil used as a liniment for aching muscles and to clear your head. Skin softener and stimulant. Used in soaps as an antiseptic and anti-inflammatory to treat wounds, acne, blemishes, boils, dandruff, dermatitis, and herpes fever blisters. Tea is used as a shampoo, conditioner, and hair rinse. Rosemary oil is often used with almond oil in scalp massages to help increase circulation and stimulate hair growth. Not recommended for pregnant women.


 

 

ROYAL JELLY

Royal jelly is the nutritious substance secreted by honeybee workers to feed colony members and the queen. Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. In capsules, increases stamina, endurance, and concentration. Neuroprotective. Enhances cognitive performance and improves memory. Lowers cholesterol, blood sugar levels, and blood pressure. May be helpful in treating nonalcoholic liver disease. Contains testosterone. Promotes calcium absorption and may be helpful in the treatment of osteoporosis. Protects the liver against chemical attack. Neuroprotective. May offer skin protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Helpful for the obese. Curbs appetite. Promotes restful sleep. Builds and promotes sex glands and restores vitality. Increases sperm count and frequency of ejaculations. Anti-aging. May prolong life. May be helpful in treating PMS. Because royal jelly has been shown to inhibit melanin synthesis, it may be helpful as a skin-whitening agent. Used topically to treat difficult-to-heal wounds and chronic itching. Common in cosmetics, food supplements, and some beverages. Some people may be allergically sensitive to royal jelly.



RUE

Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Analgesic. Anti-parasitic. Lowers LDL and total cholesterol levels, and increases beneficial HDL cholesterol levels. Anti-ulcer. Leaf extracts may be helpful in the treatment of gastric ulcers. Extracts may help to eliminate larvae and worms caused by schistosomiasis.

 

 

RUTABAGA

Can protect against breast, colon, and stomach cancer. Reduces cholesterol and constipation.

 

 

RYE

Antioxidant. Reduces blood sugar and cholesterol. Helps prevent heart disease. Rye bread is rich in fiber which helps treat constipation and improve bowels. May offer protection against toxic chemicals in the environment. Shown to suppress tumor growth. May promote a healthy prostate. Some people are gluten intolerant of rye (i.e. have celiac disease). Rye breads are higher in salt than most other store-bought breads. Dietary sodium can be a major contributor to hypertension in salt-sensitive individuals. High salt diets can also deplete the bodys calcium levels, which can increase the risk of developing osteoporosis.

 




 

S

 

 

 

 

SAFFLOWER

Antioxidant. One of the richest sources of beneficial omega-6 fatty acids, which help support the brain and nervous system. Lowers blood sugar levels. Helpful for those with metabolic syndrome. Neuroprotective. Treats hysteria, tremors, arthritis, dementia, and seizures. Oil is high in Vitamin K which is essential in the production of blood clotting proteins, improves bone metabolism, and has been shown to have anti-cancer effects (e.g. Non-Hodgkins lymphoma). Seed powder extracts can help stimulate bone formation and accelerate the healing of fractures. Cancer cell inhibitor (e.g. breast). Tumor inhibitor. Anti-ulcer. Extracts are cardioprotective, and can also protect the liver and kidneys against chemical attack. Floral extracts have been used to promote hair growth. Safflower oil lowers cholesterol and does not contribute to arterial plaque buildup. Oil is also used as a base for a better lip balm.

 

 

SAFFRON

Antioxidant. Antibacterial. Anti-inflammatory. Lower blood sugar levels. Also lowers total cholesterol and triglycerides, and increases beneficial HDL cholesterol levels. Helpful for diabetics and provides support for the pancreas. Treats coughs and colds. Nerve and heart tonic. May be helpful in the treatment of heart palpitations, cardiac arrhythmias, encephalomyelitis, glaucoma, and multiple sclerosis. Treats rheumatoid arthritis, neuropathic pain, insomnia, anxiety, stress, PMS, and mild to moderate depression. Blood cleanser and thinner. Anti-tumor and anti-ulcer. Cancer cell inhibitor (e.g. liver, prostate, leukemia). Gastroprotective and neuroprotective. Protects the liver against chemical attack. Extracts may be helpful in reducing polyps in the small intestine. Extracts can also protect the liver against nonalcoholic liver disease caused by a high fat diet. Extracts can also protect against ischemic stroke and alcohol intoxication. Treats diabetic nephropathy. Both crocin, a neuroprotective agent, and crocetin, compounds found in saffron, may be helpful in treating Alzheimers disease, and Parkinsonism, a neurologic disorder similar to Parkinsons disease. Extracts may also be helpful in treating age-related macular degeneration and light-induced retinal damage. Saffron may also be helpful in reducing the severity of symptoms in those with ulcerative colitis. Crocin can also help protect heart, liver, and brain cells. Crocin may also help relieve symptoms of chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy in cancer patients. Crocetin can help improve sleep quality, and is also antihypertensive and antithrombotic. Extracts can inhibit DNA damage caused by chemical exposure. Extracts may also be helpful in opium drug withdrawal programs. May be helpful in treating depression and anxiety. Helps relieve and improve cognition and memory problems due to poor circulation. Also treats morphine-induced memory impairment. Gel treats male erectile dysfunction. Aphrodisiac. Used in cosmetics, as a food coloring and flavoring agent, as a natural sunscreen and moisturizer, and as an additive to Arabian coffees.

 

 

SAGE

Anti-inflammatory. Antibacterial. Antimicrobial. Antifungal. Anti-yeast. Astringent. Antiseptic. Analgesic. Rich in antioxidants. High in Vitamin B6 which is critical for protein and red blood cell metabolism, for the proper functioning of the nervous and immune systems, for the maintenance of blood sugar levels, and may be protective against some cancers (e.g. colorectal and lung). Tea is used as a remedy for sore throat, tonsillitis, and laryngitis. Tea also helps inhibit breast milk flow in nursing mothers and promotes uterine contractions in pregnant women. Treats diarrhea. Liver tonic. Protects the liver and kidneys against chemical attack. Sage tea has been shown to promote liver regeneration when combined with fresh beet and tomato juices. Lowers LDL and total cholesterol levels, lowers triglycerides, and increases beneficial HDL cholesterol levels. Treats drug-induced memory impairment, and may also help restore brain function and memory in those with Alzheimer's disease. Powdered or in tea, inhibits blood clots, myocardial infarctions, and other heart problems. Roots may have a tranquilizing effect similar to Valium without the addictive side effects. Lowers blood sugar levels in diabetics. Sage helps benefit allergy sufferers by drying excessive nasal secretions. May be helpful in reducing symptoms of hot flashes in post-menopausal women. Treats peptic ulcers and lung fibrosis. Garden sage extracts treat ulcerative colitis. Chinese or red sage (Danshen) treats cardiovascular problems including angina, heart attacks and strokes. Red sage treats urolithiasis, and may also be helpful for those suffering from glaucoma or polycystic ovary syndrome. It has also been shown to inhibit the release of histamine. Neuroprotective. Helps reduce pain, neuropathy, and inflammation in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. Used in mouthwashes to treat sore gums and mouth ulcers. Dried and combined with black tea, is used as a topical hair treatment for graying hair and baldness. Crushed boiled leaves with whole-wheat flower are used as a poultice to relieve intense itchiness from allergic skin reactions such as psoriasis, eczema, poison ivy, and insect bites. Breath freshener. Water purifier. The essential oil of clary sage is used as a massage oil and aphrodisiac. Helps treat a sore throat, mouth sores, and laryngitis. Soothes mucous membranes. Sage is not recommended for pregnant women.

 

 

SAGEBRUSH

Tea can be used as a treatment for Montezuma's revenge traveler's diarrhea. Chewing twigs can help prevent dehydration. Treats sunstroke and eye inflammations. Relieves skin ailments including dandruff, ringworm, eczema, and psoriasis. Remedy for insect bites and stings.

 

 

ST. JOHN'S WORT

Antiviral. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Blood purifier. Anti-inflammatory. Floral extracts (hypericin) are used to treat mild depression and anxiety. Rich in melatonin, which is an excellent treatment for insomnia. Tension reliever. Fatigue fighter. Inhibits cancerous tumors. Neuroprotective. Possible AIDS preventative. Effective in the treatment of substance abuse problems such as alcohol and nicotine withdrawal programs. Reduces withdrawal symptoms in opium and heroin addicts. Protects the kidneys against chemical attack. Treats premature ejaculation in men. May be helpful in the treatment of stress-related memory disorders. Treats chronic uterine problems, PMS, and irregular menstruation. Helps reduce hot flashes, menopausal symptoms, and depression in postmenopausal women. Oil is used topically for pain relief due to arthritis, rheumatism, and sciatica. Ointments and creams treat external lesions, tumors, athletes foot, dermatitis, burns, and boils. Topicals help accelerate wound healing and minimize scarring in women with cesarean surgeries. Also enhances recovery in spinal cord injuries. May be helpful in treating neuralgia. Improves mental performance in diabetics. Treats winter blues and those with seasonal affective disorder. Bolsters immunity. Regulates sleep patterns. Treats asthma and diarrhea. Extracts can help lower blood sugar levels. Boosts neurotransmitter serotonin levels and cognitive function. Reduces intestinal swellings. May be helpful in treating oral bacterial and biofilms. Treats bedwetting. Ointment may help treat psoriasis. Salve for treating skin cancers including basal skin carcinomas. Oil extracts have been used to treat pressure sores in intensive care patients. Used in a cocktail with other herbs to treat cerebrospinal conditions such as hydrocephally. Protects the liver against chemical attack. Extracts have been used to treat seizures and convulsions. May be helpful for epileptics. Side effects include sunlight sensitivity, stomachaches, allergic skin reactions, fatigue, dizziness, and dry mouth. Some studies also suggest that this herb may lower the effectiveness of heart transplant drugs used to prevent organ rejection, and reduce the strength of some HIV drugs. Shown to lower the amount of the heart drug, digoxin in the body. Not recommended if you are also taking protease inhibitors, birth control pills, warfarin, cyclosporin, indinavir, or antidepressants such as Prozac. There have been numerous other reports of drug interactions associated with St. Johns wort. It is recommended that you check with your local medical doctor about these combinations before taking this herb.

 

 

SALMON

Good protein source. High in beneficial omega-3 fatty acids that help support the brain, nervous system, and prostate. Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, dementia, and Alzheimers disease. Anti-inflammatory. Lowers blood pressure. Also lowers cholesterol and raises beneficial HDL levels. Rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). One of the richest known sources of Vitamin D which is essential for cell replication, calcium absorption and metabolism, normal insulin secretion, and bone health. Vitamin D also provides protection against bone diseases, many cancers, multiple sclerosis, diabetes, gum disease, and muscle problems. Salmon is also a good source of Vitamin B12 which is essential in the production of red and white blood cells, maintenance of a healthy nervous system, and may be helpful in the prevention of dementia. Anti-inflammatory. May protect the heart against sudden attack. Fish oil may help maintain insulin levels in diabetics and improve breathing in asthma sufferers. Also treats acute respiratory distress syndrome, psoriasis, multiple sclerosis, and dysmennorrhea. Canned salmon is safe to eat because the canning process destroys any microorganisms that may be present. Salmon is high in fat and cholesterol. Processed (e.g. canned) salmon products can also be high in sodium which can be a major contributor to hypertension in salt-sensitive individuals. High salt diets can also deplete the bodys calcium levels, which can increase the risk of developing osteoporosis. Some people may also be allergically sensitive to salmon eggs. Treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, but not recommended if you have gout. Some studies have indicated that farmed Atlantic salmon products contain much higher levels of toxic chemicals such as PCBs and pesticides than wild Pacific salmon varieties.

 

 

 

SALT

Salt and salty foods have been shown to be toxic to certain harmful bacteria such as E. coli and Salmonella, which can cause food poisoning in people. Salt is an important regulator of blood pressure. Excess dietary sodium can be a major contributor to hypertension in salt-sensitive individuals. High salt diets can also deplete the bodys calcium levels, which can increase the risk of developing osteoporosis. High salt diets have also been independently linked to strokes, and have been shown to increase your risk for developing gastritis, gastric cancer, and cataracts. Some studies have suggested that adding salt to prepared meals may increase your risk of type 2 diabetes. Other research has suggested that the overconsumption of sodium can lead to erectile dysfunction in men. Studies suggest that the consumption of natural sea salt induces less hypertension compared to refined salt.

 

 

 

SAMPSON'S SNAKEROOT

Remedy for snakebites.

 

SANDLEWOOD

Antioxidant. Sandlewood oil can lower blood sugar levels.

 

 

SARDINE

Good protein source. Provides one of the richest calcium sources if eaten with the bones. High in beneficial omega-3 fatty acids that help support the brain, nervous system, and prostate. Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, dementia, and Alzheimers disease. Anti-inflammatory. Lowers blood pressure and cholesterol. Rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Rich source of Vitamin D which is essential for cell replication, calcium absorption and metabolism, normal insulin secretion, and bone health. Vitamin D also provides protection against bone diseases, many cancers, multiple sclerosis, diabetes, gum disease, and muscle problems. Sardines are also a good source of Vitamin B12 which is essential in the production of red and white blood cells, maintenance of a healthy nervous system, and may be helpful in the prevention of dementia. Anti-inflammatory. May protect the heart against sudden attack. Anti-inflammatory. Fish oil may help maintain insulin levels in diabetics and improve breathing in asthma sufferers. Also treats acute respiratory distress syndrome, psoriasis, multiple sclerosis, and dysmenorrhea. Sardines are high in fat and very high in cholesterol. Treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, but not recommended if you have gout.

 

 

SARGASSUM

SEE: SEAWEED

 

 

 

SARSAPARILLA

Powerful antibiotic. Antioxidant. Antiviral. Blood purifier. Treats rheumatism, arthritis, and gout. Diuretic. Helps balance male and female hormones. Similar effect as testosterone, an important hair-growing hormone. Tea was once used to treat venereal diseases such as syphilis and gonorrhea.

 

 

SASSAFRAS

Blood purifier. Antiseptic. Treats all skin disorders, especially acne. Stimulates liver to clear toxins from the body. Helpful in treating herpes, eczema, shingles, psoriasis, rash, rheumatism, gout, arthritis, fever, dysentery, and lung problems. Used as a smoking deterrent. Can slow milk flow in nursing mothers.

 

 

SAUERKRAUT

SEE: CABBAGE

 

 

 

SAVIN

SEE: CEDAR BERRY

 

 

SAVORY

Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Anti-aging. Tea treats diarrhea and colic. High in calcium. Calcium helps form and preserve teeth and bones and prevent osteoporosis. High in Vitamin B6 which is critical for protein and red blood cell metabolism, for the proper functioning of the nervous and immune systems, for the maintenance of blood sugar levels, and may be protective against some cancers (e.g. colorectal and lung). Treatment for sinus and allergy problems. Summer savory is an aflatoxin inhibitor. Used as an aphrodisiac. Winter savory has been used in the treatment of premature ejaculation. Water purifier.

 

 

SAW PALMETTO

Reproductive system tonic for men. Helps protect the prostate gland. Treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia and male pattern baldness. Prevents breakdown of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. Helps relax bladder muscles and relieves excessive urination. Helps balance hormone levels. Increases sperm count and improves circulation. Tonic for glands. Berries are diuretic and antiseptic. Treats hormonal diseases such as deep cystic acne and polycystic ovarian syndrome. Treatment for asthma. Also treats an irritable bladder in women. Side effects include headaches, nausea, stomachaches, and male erectile dysfunction. A few cases of pancreatitis have also been linked to saw palmetto usage.

 

SCALLION

SEE: ONION

 

SCALLOP

Scallops are a good source of protein and are low in fat. Very rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Scallops are also a rich source of Vitamin B12, which is essential in the production of red and white blood cells, maintenance of a healthy nervous system, and may be helpful in the prevention of dementia. Rich in zinc which is vital for a healthy immune system, skin repair injuries, the digestion of starchy food, thyroid hormone metabolism, and regulation of the prostate gland. Scallops are high in cholesterol. Scallops should only be eaten fully cooked. Consumption of partially cooked or raw scallops can result in gastroenteritis and diarrhea in individuals due to bacterial infection.



 

SCHISANDRA

Chinese herb. Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Antibacterial. Nervous system stimulant. Flu fighter. Liver detoxifier. Protects the liver against chemical poisonings and alcohol-induced fatty liver disease. Increases the activity of liver enzymes and accelerates liver regeneration. Cancer cell inhibitor (e.g. liver, stomach). May improve athletic performance by increasing the activity of liver enzymes that help to detoxify and eliminate the byproducts of strenuous exercise.
