Gastroprotective. Protects the stomach against alcohol-induced gastric lesions. Anti-ulcer. Treats hepatitis, depression, chronic fatigue, autoimmune disorders, and insomnia. Helps improve memory and mental function. Helpful for the obese. May help restore brain function and treat dementia in those with Alzheimer's disease. May be helpful in the treatment of acne. Considered to be a weaker version of ginseng, but safer to use in the long-term. Not recommended for epileptics, or those suffering from migraines or severe hypertension. Side effects include stomachache.

 

 

SCULLCAP

Antioxidant. Antispasmodic. Anti-inflammatory. Nerve sedative. Soothes and calms the entire nervous system. Cancer cell and tumor inhibitor. Remedy for muscle spasms, twitches, and convulsions. Treats brain hemorrhages and traumas due to stroke. Great hangover remedy. Stimulates bile flow. Helps digestion. Diuretic. Treats allergies and asthma by reducing inflammation. Lowers cholesterol. Helps reduce symptoms of arthritis. Side effects include possible liver damage.

 

 

SEA BERRY

SEE: SEA BUCKTHORN

 

 

SEA BUCKTHORN

Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Antibacterial. Berries are rich in beta-carotene, Vitamins C and E, chromium, potassium, and quercetin. Beta-carotene can help prevent the development of eye diseases such as cataracts and macular degeneration. Beta-carotene also offers protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Vitamin C boosts the immune system, helps lower blood pressure, and has been used in the prevention and treatment of many cancers. Vitamin E helps the body synthesize red blood cells, inhibits free radicals that can harm cells, helps the body to use Vitamin K, and protects the heart. Chromium regulates insulin and helps normalize blood sugar. Potassium helps regulate blood pressure, promote a steady heartbeat, and lower your risk of stroke. Quercetin is a natural antioxidant, anti-inflammatory and antihistamine which is helpful for those with allergies and respiratory problems. Quercetin also protects cells against DNA and UV-induced sunlight damage, helps prevent alcohol-induced liver disease, lowers your blood pressure and risk of heart disease and stroke, lowers blood sugar and cholesterol, protects against tumors and ulcers, is neuroprotective, and inhibits cancer. Cancer cell inhibitor (e.g. prostate). Seed oil can lower total serum cholesterol and triglycerides, lower harmful LDL, and raise beneficial HDL levels. Also lowers blood pressure and blood sugar levels. Protects the liver and kidney against chemical attack. May be helpful in treating nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Seed extracts have shown an ability to inhibit the growth of leukemia cells, and are protective against light-induced retinal degeneration. Extracts have been shown to provide protection against arsenic, lead, and radiation exposure. Berries can also protect against acrylamide-induced neurotoxicity. Extracts can also protect tissues against nicotine-induced organ damage, and have shown promise in treating dengue. Fruit extracts may be helpful in the treatment of mental disorders such as schizophrenia. Leaf extracts help strengthen the immune system in the elderly. Helpful for the obese. Also helpful for those who are recovering from post-stress hypothermia exposure. Treats fatigue and stress due to excessive exercise. Oil helps treat symptoms of dry eye. Also treats skin problems such as atopic dermatitis, wrinkling, acne, wounds, and eczema. The oils and juice from this plant are used as food additives in candies, jams, jellies, and alcoholic beverages. Also used in cosmetics, soaps, shampoos, sunscreens, and other products.

 

 

 

SEAL

 

Seal meat (not blubber) is a very rich source of protein and is low in fat. Seal meat is also high in iron, zinc, Vitamins A, B12, and D. Iron vitalizes blood cells and keeps your immune system healthy. Zinc is vital for a healthy immune system, skin repair injuries, the digestion of starchy food, thyroid hormone metabolism, and regulation of the prostate gland. Vitamin A helps form and maintain teeth, tissues, and skin. Vitamin A also produces pigments that are essential for good vision. Vitamin B12 is essential in the production of red and white blood cells, maintenance of a healthy nervous system, and may be helpful in the prevention of dementia. Good source of Vitamin D which is essential for cell replication, calcium absorption and metabolism, normal insulin secretion, and bone health. Vitamin D also provides protection against bone diseases, many cancers, multiple sclerosis, diabetes, gum disease, and muscle problems. Seal oil may be helpful in treating breast cancer. Seal meat may contain high levels of mercury and should be consumed sparingly.

 

 

 

 

SEAWEED

Antiviral. Antifungal. Antibacterial. Anti-inflammatory. Immune system booster. Lowers blood sugar levels and cholesterol. Salt substitute. Rich source of iodine, which is necessary to produce thyroid hormone, which regulates the body's energy level, and is essential for fetal and childhood brain development. Depression and loss of sex drive can be due to an underactive thyroid, which can be triggered by iodine deficiency. Rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). High in Vitamin K which is essential in the production of blood clotting proteins, improves bone metabolism, and has been shown to have anti-cancer effects (e.g. Non-Hodgkins lymphoma). Excellent for hair and nails. Reduces hay fever in allergy sufferers. Marine algae are high in iron, which vitalizes blood cells and keeps your immune system healthy. Seaweed is also a rich source of calcium. Calcium helps form and preserve teeth and bones and prevent osteoporosis. Some seaweeds have been used to help control obesity. Seaweeds are low in fat and calories, and are high in fiber. Fiber helps increase elimination. Some algal species have been used in bioremediation programs to help remove toxic metals such as cadmium and mercury from the environment. Some people are sensitive to high iodine concentrations.

Agar-agar is the dried extract from marine algae. Treats chronic constipation. Similar to bran in that it can be used as a bulk laxative. Agar should always be consumed with large amounts of water.

Bladderwrack (seawrack) is one of the best herbs for treating obesity. Good for glandular afflictions. Lowers cholesterol. Treatment for goiter. Also used in beauty treatments. Shown to increase the length of the menstrual cycle in women, reduce blood flow, and reduce the average number of days of menstruation in pre-menopausal women.

Blue-green algae (spirulina) extracts can lower cholesterol, reduce clotting, and have shown some effectiveness against the AIDS virus in clinical trials. Antiviral. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Anti-inflammatory. Antihistamine. Analgesic. Antioxidant. Spirulina is considered to be a complete protein source. Rich source of beta-carotene. Beta-carotene can help prevent the development of eye diseases such as cataracts and macular degeneration. Beta-carotene also offers protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Spirulina is among the richest sources of arginine, an amino acid which has been shown to increase the bodys production of nitric oxide. Nitric oxide helps dilate blood vessels, lower blood pressure, and improve blood circulation to the heart, brain, and bladder. Arginine therapy has been used to reduce the parasite burden in the treatment of severe malaria and leishmaniasis. Spirulina is rich in zeaxanthin, a carotenoid that helps reduce the risk of cataracts and age-related macular degeneration. Spirulina is also a rich source of potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure, promote a steady heartbeat, and lower your risk of stroke. Neuroprotective. May be helpful in treating cognitive deficits and dementia. May also protect against neural tube defects. Protects the brain, liver, kidneys, and other organs from mercury, lead, cadmium, nicotine, and other toxic chemical exposure. Immune system booster. Cancer cell inhibitor (e.g. liver). Anti-ulcer. Treatment for bronchial asthma and hay fever. Blood sugar regulator and tonifier. Helpful for those with metabolic syndrome, the obese, and those with Type 1 diabetes. Lowers blood pressure and blood sugar levels. Good food supplement for the undernourished. Treats arthritis, gout, and anemia. Helps suppress appetite. Not recommended if you have kidney stones or have a family history of stone formation.

Brown algae (kelp) has shown anti-cancer and anti-tumor activity. May reduce the risk of hormone-dependent cancers in women. Treats hypothyroidism. Anticoagulant. Immune system stimulant. Antioxidant. Lowers blood sugar levels and cholesterol. Antibacterial. Antiviral. As with blue-green algae, extracts show some promise against the AIDS virus. Brown algae have also shown the ability to inhibit parasitic infections that cause trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease).

Chlorella are unicellular green marine microalgae that also show similar traits to other algae. Antiviral. Anti-inflammatory. Antihistamine. Anti-tumor. Analgesic. Potent antioxidant. Cancer cell and tumor inhibitor (e.g. breast, lung). Lowers blood sugar levels, blood pressure, and cholesterol. Chlorella powder, a dietary supplement, contains lutein, a carotenoid which accumulates in the retina. Luteins improve visual function and can help prevent eye diseases such as age-related cataracts and macular degeneration. Chlorella has been shown to block the absorption of heterocyclic amines which are considered to be carcinogenic substances produced by the cooking process. Helpful for the obese. Immune system stimulant. Improves physical stamina. Treats cystitis, fibromyalgia, non-alcoholic liver disease, and mild hypertension. Helps reduce the risk of anemia and edema in pregnant women. Shown to reduce dioxin levels in breast milk. May be helpful in the prevention or treatment of depression and diabetes. Protects the liver, kidneys, and brain from chemical attack and toxic cadmium and lead exposure.

Dulse (palmaria) (rhodymenia) are edible red algae that are used to treat hypothyroidism. Antioxidant. Salt substitute. Extracts contain anti-tumor compounds.

Hijiki (hiziki) (Sargassum) is a brown algae used in Traditional Chinese Medicine to treat goiter and high blood pressure. Rich in minerals and high in fiber. Antioxidant. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Anti-inflammatory. Analgesic. Lowers cholesterol. Cancer cell inhibitor (e.g. liver). Anti-tumor. Helps treat osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and gastritis. Protects the liver and kidneys against chemical attack. Some Sargassum species extracts (e.g. S. ringgoldianum and S. homeri), respectively, can help lower blood sugar levels and treat allergies. Others (e.g. S. polycystum) may be helpful in protecting organs such as the kidney and liver against damage caused by diabetes. Helpful for the obese. Use caution when consuming hijiki seaweed since some studies have revealed the presence of high levels of arsenic which is carcinogenic to humans.

Irish moss (chondrus) helps reduce high blood pressure. Extracts may help treat ulcers. Cancer cell inhibitor.

Nori algae (porphyra) (gim) contains anti-tumor compounds. Cancer cell inhibitor. Lowers blood sugar levels and cholesterol. High in protein. Anti-inflammatory. Extracts also offer protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. It is often used as a wrap for rice in sushi. Use caution when consuming nori seaweed since some studies have revealed the presence of high levels of arsenic which is carcinogenic to humans.

Wakame (undaria) (miyeok) is high in protein. Antiviral. Anti-inflammatory. Cancer cell inhibitor. Treatment for herpes simplex. Immune system stimulant. Lowers blood pressure. Helps reduce the bodys absorption of dioxin. Wakame is high in sodium which can be a major contributor to hypertension in salt-sensitive individuals. High salt diets can also deplete the bodys calcium levels, which can increase the risk of developing osteoporosis.

 

 

 

SEAWRACK

SEE: SEAWEED

 

 

 

SEEDS

Plant seeds may protect against prostate, breast, and colon cancers.

SEE ALSO: SPECIFIC SEEDS

 

 

SENNA

Indian herb is a strong laxative. Antioxidant. Antimicrobial. Treats stubborn constipation. Stimulates colon contractions. Prevents fluids from being absorbed into the large intestine. Treats constipation, intestinal gas, and bloating. Colon cleaner and detoxifier. Tumor inhibitor. Extracts can lower cholesterol levels, and may be helpful in the treatment of prostate cancer. Protects the liver against chemical attack. The extracts of some species (e.g. S. spectabilis) have shown leishmanicidal and anticonvulsant activity. May cause severe cramping and abdominal distress in high doses. Not recommended for pregnant women or for long-term use.


 

 

SESAME

Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Seeds are rich in protein. Natural laxative. Sesame seeds contain an oil called sesamin which is a powerful antioxidant that lowers blood sugar levels, lowers blood pressure and cholesterol, and does not contribute to arterial plaque buildup. Sesamin can help repair liver injury due to high cholesterol. Sesamin also treats rheumatoid arthritis, and reduces anxiety induced by chronic pain. Sesamin may be protective against diabetes-associated cognitive decline. Sesamin may also be helpful in improving lead-induced learning and memory deficits. Tonic for the liver and kidneys. Cardioprotective. Seed extracts and oil can protect the kidneys, liver, and heart against chemical attack. Sesamol, an anti-inflammatory compound found in the oil, protects the kidneys and is helpful for diabetics because it reduces symptoms and inflammation caused by diabetic neuropathy. Sesamol may also help improve asthma symptoms, and also has shown an ability to inhibit melanin synthesis and reduce UVB-induced skin hyperpigmentation. Both sesamin and sesamol have shown promise as cancer cell and tumor inhibitors. Sesamol has shown an ability to protect against gamma radiation-induced cellular DNA damage. Sesamol can also be used as a wound healer. Sesame oil reduces joint pain, and has been used to treat arthritis and infusion or chemotherapy-induced phlebitis, a common side effect of intravenous cancer chemotherapy. Sesame oil is also neuroprotective, and can protect against cerebral ischemia and memory impairment induced by inflammation. Warmed sesame oil can be used in eardrops to help soften hardened or excessive wax buildup, and as eye drops to treat eye disorders such as glaucoma, myopia, and trachoma. Sesame seed kernels are among the richest sources of zinc. Zinc is vital for a healthy immune system, skin repair injuries, the digestion of starchy food, thyroid hormone metabolism, and regulation of the prostate gland. Sesame seed cakes can help lower blood sugar levels, reduce cholesterol, and help lower weight in the obese. Black sesame seeds strengthen the reproductive system and may help prevent hair from graying. Sesame seeds contain compounds that may be helpful in preventing cognitive decline. Seed extracts are a natural pain reliever. Chewed or ground seeds are used as a poultice to treat insect bites, skin sores, burns, and pimples. Seeds are a rich source of calcium. Calcium helps form and preserve teeth and bones and prevent osteoporosis. Seeds are also high in magnesium, which is a natural tranquilizer and helps the body to regulate cholesterol and blood sugar levels. Magnesium is also good for relief of migraines and helps slow bone loss. Floral extracts have shown anti-tumor qualities. Some people may be allergically sensitive to sesame.


 

SHALLOT

SEE: ONION

 

SHANKAPULSHPI

Treatment for epileptic seizures. Not recommended for use with other anti-seizure drugs.

 

 

 

SHARK

 

Good protein source. High in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Anti-inflammatory. Cartilage is used to treat arthritis. May help rejuvenate cartilage in injured joints. Treats canine lameness. Shark meat is high in cholesterol. Shark may also contain high levels of mercury and should be consumed sparingly.

 

 

 

SHATAVARI

SEE: ASPARAGUS

 

 

SHAVEGRASS

SEE: HORSETAIL

 

 

SHEEP SORREL

Remedy for kidney trouble. Expels foreign matter from kidneys.

 

 

SHEPHERD'S PURSE

Hemostatic. Tea helps regulate hemorrhaging after childbirth. Helps stop nosebleeds, excess menstruation, bleeding hemorrhoids, bloody urine, and bloody stools. Treats external muscular disorders. Antibacterial. Anti-inflammatory. Possible ulcer preventative.

 

 

SHRIMP

Shrimp is a good source of protein and is low in fat. Rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Shrimp is also a good source of Vitamin B12 which is essential in the production of red and white blood cells, maintenance of a healthy nervous system, and may be helpful in the prevention of dementia. Shrimp is high in arginine, an amino acid which has been shown to increase the bodys production of nitric oxide. Nitric oxide helps dilate blood vessels, lower blood pressure, and improve blood circulation to the heart, brain, and bladder. Arginine therapy has also been used to treat lead intoxication and reduce the parasite burden in the treatment of severe malaria and leishmaniasis. Shrimp is high in cholesterol. Shrimp should only be eaten fully cooked. Consumption of partially cooked or raw shrimp can result in gastroenteritis and diarrhea in individuals due to bacterial infection.



 

SIBERIAN GINSENG

SEE: GINSENG

 

 

SKUNK CABBAGE

Treats respiratory problems including asthma and dry coughs. Helpful for chronic rheumatism and nervous system conditions such as muscular spasms and hysteria. Used externally as an ointment for skin irritations.

 

 

SLIPPERY ELM

Strong antioxidant. Treats chronic inflammation. Digestive aid. Elm lemonade is one of the best herbs for those recovering from mild or serious illness. Bark tea treats coughs, sore throats, and appendicitis. Bark also helps soothe an irritated respiratory tract. Remedy for sores, boils, and eczema. Lozenges are used to treat smoking addiction. Treatment for irritable bowel syndrome, diarrhea, and constipation. Normalizes bowels. Cleans the colon. Bark and root extracts have shown an ability to inhibit cell growth in endometrial and colon cancers. Good for gastric or duodenal ulcers, acid reflux, hemorrhoids, kidney problems, lung, and eye pain. Used topically to speed the healing of deep wounds.

 

 

SMARTWEED

Tea used as a hemostat to stop bleeding.



SNAIL

Snails are a good source of protein and are low in fat. High in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Good source of Vitamin E which helps the body synthesize red blood cells, inhibits free radicals that can harm cells, helps the body to use Vitamin K, and protects the heart. Powdered snails have been used to protect the liver against chemical attack. Snails should only be eaten fully cooked. Consumption of partially cooked or raw snails can result in gastroenteritis and diarrhea in individuals due to bacterial infection. Occasionally, it can also result in roundworm infection (e.g. rat lungworm), and meningitis in some cases.

 

 

SNAKEROOT

 

Ageratina. Used in the treatment of nail fungal infections (e.g. onychomycosis).



 

 

SNAP DRAGON

Treats numerous eye disorders including cataracts and conjunctivitis. Floral extracts are cancer cell inhibitors (e.g. lung, colon).

 

 

SOAPWORT

Used as a hair shampoo. Treats dandruff and other skin irritations. Contains saponin, which was used by the Chinese in detergents for washing clothes.

 

 

SOLOMON'S SEAL

Anti-inflammatory. Solomon's seal root tea can be used as a topical to treat poison ivy and to wash out wounds. Contains allantoin, a proven skin and wound healer that promotes the growth of connective tissue. Allantoin may also be helpful in the treatment of hypertension. Extracts have been shown to lower blood sugar levels and cholesterol.

 

 

SORGHUM

Antioxidant. Antiviral. Antifungal. Anti-inflammatory. Extracts have shown promise in the treatment of anemia. Extracts can also lower blood sugar and cholesterol levels. Tumor and cancer cell inhibitor. Cancer preventative (e.g. colon). High in fiber which helps increase elimination. Sorghum beverages (made from stems) are high in magnesium which is a natural tranquilizer and helps the body to regulate cholesterol and blood sugar levels. Magnesium is also good for relief of migraines and helps slow bone loss. Sorghum drinks are also a good source of iron which vitalizes blood cells and keeps your immune system healthy. Can be eaten safely by those who are gluten intolerant (i.e. those who have celiac disease). Used in animal feeds and food coloring.

 

 

SORREL

Rich in Vitamin C which boosts the immune system, helps lower blood pressure, and has been used in the prevention and treatment of many cancers. Tea helps reduce painful gall and kidney stones. Gargle for sore mouths and throat.

 

 

SOY

Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Antiviral. Immune system booster. Lowers blood pressure and cholesterol, and protects against heart disease. A high intake of soy foods is associated with a lower risk of type 2 diabetes and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Soy is the only vegetable source of complete protein. Soybeans and tofu (coagulated soymilk or bean curd) are high in calcium and Vitamin E. Calcium helps form and preserve teeth and bones and prevent osteoporosis. Soybean oil is ranked among the highest sources of Vitamin E compared to other plant oils. Vitamin E helps the body synthesize red blood cells, inhibits free radicals that can harm cells, helps the body to use Vitamin K, and protects the heart. Soy is also a good source of B-vitamins. Soy protein helps improve kidney function and reduce glomerulus sclerosis. Soy foods can increase the levels of beneficial Bifidobacteria and Lactobacilli in the gut and help reduce levels of pathogenic bacterial populations, which may help lower the risk of disease and promote health. Soybean extracts can also protect the kidney against chemical attack. Soybeans and soybean flour contain magnesium, which is a natural tranquilizer and helps the body to regulate cholesterol and blood sugar levels. Magnesium is also good for relief of migraines and helps slow bone loss. Tempe (a fermented soybean cake), miso (a soybean paste), and soy sauce, are all rich in enzymes that help metabolize food. Tempe is rich in folic acid which is essential for DNA synthesis and repair, and has been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, fetal neural tube defects, cervical dysplasia, heart disease, bowel problems, and certain cancers (e.g. oral, pharyngeal, bladder, colorectal, and pancreas). Douchi, made from fermented soybeans, can be used topically to treat skin lesions and atopic dermatitis. Soybean oil is high in antioxidants and Vitamin K which is essential in the production of blood clotting proteins, improves bone metabolism, and has been shown to have anti-cancer effects (e.g. Non-Hodgkins lymphoma). Oil is also high in beneficial omega-3 fatty acids, which help support the brain, nervous system, and prostate. Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, dementia, and Alzheimers disease. Contains biotin, which is good for faster hair growth, fewer split ends, and stronger fingernails. An 8-ounce daily soymilk serving can protect the prostate gland. Soybean flour is rich in iron, which vitalizes blood cells and keeps your immune system healthy. Protects against the negative effects of testosterone in men and estrogen in women. Provides bone support (reduces bone loss) in peri- and postmenopausal women. Soy may provide an alternative to hormone replacement therapy in decreasing bone loss due to postmenopausal estrogen deficiency. Soy germ extracts may help reduce menopausal hot flushes. Tofu consumption may reduce your risk of anemia. Eating tofu has been shown to significantly reduce blood lead concentrations. Soy-based formula is safe for infants. Some studies suggest that soy formulas may be a good alternative for infants that are at risk for atopic dermatitis due to cows milk allergies. Soy compounds (isoflavones) can inhibit DNA damage caused by chemical exposure, and may be helpful in treating colitis. Soy isoflavones can also protect against cognitive deficits induced by chronic sleep deprivation. Soy compounds also offer protection against UV-induced sunlight damage (are anti-aging) and other sources of radiation such as gamma rays. For soy foods, tofu ranks among the highest in concentrations of isoflavones (soy milk is one of the lowest). Soy isoflavones have also been shown to reduce arterial stiffness. Maternal consumption of soy products during pregnancy may be protective against childhood hyperactivity problems in children. Soybeans contain daidzein, an isoflavone which has been shown to inhibit breast cancer cells and is neuroprotective. Some studies suggest that when soy is consumed during childhood and/or adolescence, the risk of developing breast cancer is markedly reduced. Soy consumption can lower your risk of an acute myocardial infarction. Soy products can protect the liver against chemical attack. Genistein, a naturally occurring anti-inflammatory, neuroprotective, and radioprotective compound found in red clover and soy products, has been shown to inhibit liver infection by malarial parasites. Genistein can protect the liver against chemical attack. Genistein is also a cancer cell inhibitor. Soy protein extracts have been shown to reduce mercury absorption from contaminated fish. Soymilk products have been used to treat alcoholic hangovers. Soy contains compounds that ease arthritic pain and inflammation. Soy flour/protein or tofu reduces hot flashes and night sweats. Soy may help to prevent periodontal disease. Inhibits tumor growth. Shown to be protective against leukemia, breast, lung, prostate, endometrial, ovarian, stomach, bladder, oral, and colon cancers. Some people may be allergically sensitive to soy. Miso and soy sauce are high in sodium which can be a major contributor to hypertension in salt-sensitive individuals. High salt diets can also deplete the bodys calcium levels, which can increase the risk of developing osteoporosis.



 

SPAGHETTI

SEE: WHEAT

 

 

 

SPEARMINT

Antioxidant. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Anti-inflammatory. Aflatoxin inhibitor. Aromatic. Analgesic. Stimulant. Lowers blood sugar levels and cholesterol. Dried spearmint is high in Vitamin B6 which is critical for protein and red blood cell metabolism, for the proper functioning of the nervous and immune systems, for the maintenance of blood sugar levels, and may be protective against some cancers (e.g. colorectal and lung). Breath freshener. Good for headache relief. Treats mild indigestion, intestinal gas, heartburn, and nausea. Tea soothes the nervous system and helps treat anxiety and insomnia. Extracts may be help improve cognitive performance and treat age-associated memory impairment. Spearmint oil has been used to reduce pain after caesarian section. Spearmint tea has the ability to reduce testosterone levels in women with mild hirsutism. Spearmint may be helpful in the treatment of osteoarthritis pain. Spearmint extracts have shown the ability to suppress and shrink connective tissue and skin tumors. Spearmint extracts may also be helpful in protecting the liver against nicotine-induced damage. Spearmint plants have been used in bioremediation programs to help remove heavy metals from polluted soils and sludges.

 

 

SPEEDWELL

Treats problems of the respiratory tract, gastrointestinal tract, liver, kidney, and lower urinary tract. Cough remedy. Expectorant. Provides pain relief from gout and rheumatism. Speedwell is very bitter, but in tea can be made more palatable by combining with Chinese licorice. Leaves can be used to soften hardened skin. Shown to promote ulcer healing.

 

 

 

SPELT

Grain alternative to wheat. High in protein and fiber. Fiber helps increase elimination. Easier to digest than wheat. Can be eaten safely by those who are gluten intolerant (i.e. those who have celiac disease).

 

 

 

SPIKENARD

Antioxidant. Treatment for general skin disorders including acne, pimples, blackheads, and rashes. Good for coughs, colds, and all chest afflictions. Treatment for chronic fatigue syndrome. Neuroprotective. Also radioprotective. Treats orofacial dyskinesia and catalepsy.

 

 

 

SPINACH

Extremely nutritious. Rich in antioxidants. Anti-inflammatory. Antibacterial. Good source of beta-carotene, folic acid (Vitamin B9), Vitamins A, D, E, and K. Beta-carotene can help prevent the development of eye diseases such as cataracts and macular degeneration. Beta-carotene also offers protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Folic acid is essential for DNA synthesis and repair, and has been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, fetal neural tube defects, cervical dysplasia, heart disease, bowel problems, and certain cancers (e.g. oral, pharyngeal, bladder, colorectal, and pancreas). Vitamin A helps form and maintain teeth, tissues, and skin. Vitamin A also produces pigments that are essential for good vision. Vitamin D is essential for cell replication, calcium absorption and metabolism, normal insulin secretion, and bone health. Vitamin D also provides protection against bone diseases, many cancers, multiple sclerosis, diabetes, gum disease, and muscle problems. Vitamin E helps the body synthesize red blood cells, inhibits free radicals that can harm cells, helps the body to use Vitamin K, and protects the heart. Vitamin K is essential in the production of blood clotting proteins, improves bone metabolism, and has been shown to have anti-cancer effects (e.g. Non-Hodgkins lymphoma). Spinach contains quercetin, a natural antioxidant, anti-inflammatory and antihistamine, which is helpful for those with allergies and respiratory problems. Quercetin also protects cells against DNA and UV-induced sunlight damage, helps prevent alcohol-induced liver disease, lowers your blood pressure and risk of heart disease and stroke, lowers blood sugar and cholesterol, protects against tumors and ulcers, is neuroprotective, and inhibits cancer. Frozen spinach is one of the richest sources of carotenoids such as lutein, a carotenoid which accumulates in the retina. Luteins improve visual function and can help prevent eye diseases such as age-related cataracts and macular degeneration. Spinach extracts have also been shown to reduce retinal degeneration. Blood tonifier. Colon cancer and tumor inhibitor. Shown to inhibit the growth of liver cancer cells. Used for angina pain relief. Rich calcium source. Calcium helps form and preserve teeth and bones and prevent osteoporosis. Among the highest fiber sources for any vegetable. Fiber helps increase elimination. Treats inflammatory bowel disease. Frozen spinach is very rich in arginine, an amino acid which has been shown to increase the bodys production of nitric oxide. Nitric oxide helps dilate blood vessels, lower blood pressure, and improve blood circulation to the heart, brain, and bladder. Arginine therapy has also been used to treat lead intoxication and reduce the parasite burden in the treatment of severe malaria and leishmaniasis. Treats yeast infections. Good source of magnesium, which is a natural tranquilizer and helps the body to regulate cholesterol and blood sugar levels. Magnesium is also good for relief of migraines and helps slow bone loss. High in potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure, promote a steady heartbeat, and lower your risk of stroke. Uncooked spinach is high in glutathione, a highly potent antioxidant, which is essential to the function and integrity of the cells, tissues, and organs. Improves memory. May be helpful in slowing age-related nervous system and cognitive behavioral problems. Shown to protect the liver against chemical attack and radiation damage. Extracts can decrease the accumulation of arsenic in tissues and organs. Spinach ointment and extracts have been used to heal wounds and regenerate diabetic ulcers. Spinach is high in sodium which can be a major contributor to hypertension in salt-sensitive individuals. High salt diets can also deplete the bodys calcium levels, which can increase the risk of developing osteoporosis.



 

SPIRULINA

SEE: SEAWEED

 

 

SPRAT

High in beneficial omega-3 fatty acids that help support the brain, nervous system, and prostate. Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, dementia, and Alzheimers disease. Anti-inflammatory. Lowers blood pressure and cholesterol. Rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Rich source of Vitamin D which is essential for cell replication, calcium absorption and metabolism, normal insulin secretion, and bone health. Vitamin D also provides protection against bone diseases, many cancers, multiple sclerosis, diabetes, gum disease, and muscle problems. Anti-inflammatory. May protect the heart against sudden attack. Fish oil may help maintain insulin levels in diabetics and improve breathing in asthma sufferers. Also treats acute respiratory distress syndrome, psoriasis, multiple sclerosis, and dysmennorrhea. Treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, but not recommended if you have gout.

 

 

 

SPRUCE

Piceatannol, a compound found in the roots, is a cancer and tumor inhibitor. Blue spruce leaf tea has been used to treat mouth sores and scurvy.

 

 

SQUASH

SEE: PUMPKIN

 

 

SQUAW VINE

One of the best herbs for pregnancy. Facilitates childbirth and may help prevent miscarriages. Relieves a congested uterus and ovaries. Reduces menstrual cramps. Eyewash for babies and the elderly. Treatment for insomnia.

 

 

 

SQUID

Squid is a good source of protein. Very rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Squid is also a good source of Vitamin B12, which is essential in the production of red and white blood cells, maintenance of a healthy nervous system, and may be helpful in the prevention of dementia. Squid are rich in arginine, an amino acid which has been shown to increase the bodys production of nitric oxide. Nitric oxide helps dilate blood vessels, lower blood pressure, and improve blood circulation to the heart, brain, and bladder. Arginine therapy has also been used to treat lead intoxication and reduce the parasite burden in the treatment of severe malaria and leishmaniasis. Squid ink may be helpful in the treatment of iron deficiency anemia. Squid is high in fat and very high in cholesterol. Squid should only be eaten fully cooked. Consumption of partially cooked or raw squid can result in gastroenteritis and diarrhea in individuals due to bacterial infection.

 

 

 

STAR ANISE

Chinese herb is used to treat rheumatism and lumbago. Antioxidant. Antiviral. Antifungal. Antibacterial. Anti-inflammatory. Tumor inhibitor. Mild stimulant. Diuretic. Seeds have been used to treat a toothache. The oil is given to children to help relieve colic. Provides relief from intestinal gas. Extracts can help treat atopic dermatitis. Used in herbal tea mixtures.

 

 

 

STEVIA

Sweet leaf. South American herb is used as a natural sweetener. Sugar substitute contains no saccharin or aspartame. Antioxidant. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Anti-inflammatory. Lowers blood pressure. Blood sugar regulator. Shown to reduce insulin resistance in diabetics. May be helpful in treating impaired glucose regulation, which is a metabolic status between normal glucose homeostasis and diabetes. Shown to lower triglyceride levels and raise beneficial HDL levels. Stevia leaves are a rich source of carotenoids such as lutein and zeaxanthin which accumulate in the retina. Luteins improve visual function and can help prevent eye diseases such as age-related cataracts and macular degeneration. May help reduce weight gain. Leaf extracts have been used topically to treat and heal wounds. Extracts may also be helpful in treating kidney disease.

 

 

 

STINGING NETTLES

SEE: NETTLES

 

 

STONE ROOT

Strong diuretic. Used in the treatment and prevention of kidney stones.

 

 

 

STRAWBERRY

Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Antiviral. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Analgesic. Rich source of Vitamin C which boosts the immune system, helps lower blood pressure, and has been used in the prevention and treatment of many cancers. Contains lycopene, a potent antioxidant, which has been found to be protective against heart disease, cataracts, diabetes, and numerous cancers including skin, colorectal, gastric, lung, breast, pancreatic, ovarian, cervical, prostate, liver, and bladder. Lycopene can also protect the liver and kidneys against radiation damage and chemical attack. Lycopene is also an ulcer and tumor inhibitor, and is protective against gastroesophageal reflex disease. Higher serum lycopene levels can also reduce the risk of stroke and mortality from metabolic syndrome. Lycopene may be helpful in treating infertile men who have a low sperm count. Lycopene is also neuroprotective, and may protect against age-associated memory loss and cognitive defects. Cancer cell inhibitor. Strawberries are also rich in ellagic acid, which is thought to be responsible for the anti-cancer effect. Ellagic acid, a neuroprotective and gastroprotective compound, has also shown some anti-malarial and anti-epileptic properties. Ellagic acid may also be helpful in promoting hair growth in testosterone-induced alopecia. Rich in anthocyanins which may lower ones risk for colon cancer. Anthocyanins may also offer protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Extracts may be helpful in reducing DNA damage in Alzheimers disease patients. Strawberry supplementation has been shown to increase the abundance of beneficial bacteria Bifidobacterium which play a pivotal role in the metabolism of anthocyanins. Strawberries may be helpful in reducing pain and inflammation in obese adults who have knee osteoarthritis. Strawberries contain xylitol, a naturally occurring sugar alcohol, that has been shown to reduce dental caries. Good fiber source which helps increase elimination. Neutralizes free radicals. Blocks tartar buildup on teeth. Neuroprotective. Improves cognition. May offer protection against age-related memory declines. Leaf extracts are cardioprotective. Anti-allergy. Treats atopic dermatitis. Used as a mouthwash and gargle for infections. Used to treat muscular paralysis due to electric shock, hypertension, and skin cancer. In cream form, one of the best skin cleaners.

 

 

STURGEON

Good protein source. High in beneficial omega-3 fatty acids that help support the brain, nervous system, and prostate. Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, dementia, and Alzheimers disease. Anti-inflammatory. Lowers blood pressure and cholesterol. High in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Rich source of Vitamin B12 which is essential in the production of red and white blood cells, maintenance of a healthy nervous system, and may be helpful in the prevention of dementia. Good source of Vitamin A which helps form and maintain teeth, tissues, and skin. Vitamin A also produces pigments that are essential for good vision. Anti-inflammatory. May protect the heart against sudden attack. Fish oil may help maintain insulin levels in diabetics and improve breathing in asthma sufferers. Also treats acute respiratory distress syndrome, psoriasis, multiple sclerosis, and dysmennorrhea. Sturgeon is high in cholesterol. Treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, but not recommended if you have gout.

 

 

SUGAR

Excellent disinfectant. Sprinkle granulated sugar or sugar paste on deep and seriously infected wounds to kill bacteria and reduce odor. Smear Vaseline around the wound to hold the sugar in place. A tablespoon of pure white sugar is a good cure for hiccups. Sugar water in the form of dextrose injections (prolotherapy) has been used in the treatment of chronic pain. Sugarcane juice is high in antioxidants and is used in the treatment of jaundice and other liver problems. The leaves and juice possess strong ability to protect against DNA damage. Sugarcane juice can also protect the liver against alcohol damage. Sugarcane leaf extracts are also anti-ulcer. Heavy dietary sugar consumption (e.g. in the form of sugar-sweetened beverages) can stress the kidneys, raise blood pressure and blood sugar levels, and predispose individuals to a higher risk of hypertension and diabetes.

 

SUGAR APPLE

Antioxidant. Antifungal. Anti-tumor. Anti-ulcer. Cancer cell inhibitor. Lowers blood sugar levels in diabetics. High in quercetin, a natural antioxidant, anti-inflammatory and antihistamine, which is helpful for those with allergies and respiratory problems. Quercetin also protects cells against DNA and UV-induced sunlight damage, helps prevent alcohol-induced liver disease, lowers your blood pressure and risk of heart disease and stroke, lowers blood sugar and cholesterol, protects against tumors and ulcers, is neuroprotective, and inhibits cancer. Leaf extracts can be used topically to treat wounds. Seed extracts, also used topically, may be helpful in treating psoriasis.

 

 

SUMA

Brazilian ginseng. Tonic for women. High in iron, which vitalizes blood cells and keeps your immune system healthy. Treats anemia, fatigue, and PMS. Helps lower blood sugar levels of diabetics. Possible cancer preventative.

 

 

SUMAC

Antioxidant. Antimicrobial. Antibacterial. Anti-inflammatory. Tea used as an excellent skin cleanser for treatment of venereal disease and poison ivy rashes. Smooth sumac berries have been used to open air passageways in asthma sufferers and to treat diarrhea. Protects liver and kidneys against chemical attack. Fruit extracts have shown promise in lowering blood sugar levels. Extracts may be helpful in the treatment of gastric ulcers and necrotizing enterocolitis. Helpful for the obese. Sumac powder may be helpful in treating nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Exercise caution because some sumac species are poisonous and should not be consumed.

 

 

SUNFLOWER

Antioxidant. Diuretic. Seeds are rich in protein. Leaves are anti-inflammatory. One of the richest sources of beneficial omega-6 fatty acids, which help support the brain and nervous system. Oil lowers cholesterol and does not contribute to arterial plaque buildup. Seeds are high in Vitamins B, D, E, phosphorus, iron, zinc, and selenium. Vitamin D is essential for cell replication, calcium absorption and metabolism, normal insulin secretion, and bone health. Vitamin D also provides protection against bone diseases, many cancers, multiple sclerosis, diabetes, gum disease, and muscle problems. Seed kernels are among the highest sources of natural Vitamin E that helps the body synthesize red blood cells, inhibits free radicals that can harm cells, helps the body to use Vitamin K, and protects the heart. Iron vitalizes blood cells and keeps your immune system healthy. Zinc is vital for a healthy immune system, skin repair injuries, the digestion of starchy food, thyroid hormone metabolism, and regulation of the prostate gland. Rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Seeds are a good source of calcium, which helps form and preserve teeth and bones and prevent osteoporosis. Seeds are high in potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure, promote a steady heartbeat, and lower your risk of stroke. Sunflower seeds are considered a tonic for the eyes, decreasing light sensitivity, and preventing eye degeneration. Seeds are also high in arginine, an amino acid which has been shown to increase the body's production of nitric oxide. Nitric oxide helps dilate blood vessels, lower blood pressure, and improve blood circulation to the heart, brain, and bladder. Arginine therapy has also been used to treat lead intoxication and reduce the parasite burden in the treatment of severe malaria and leishmaniasis. Seeds can also help reduce pain (analgesic), stop nicotine cravings, and may help impotence problems. Sunflower petals have been used as an effective topical mosquito repellent. Tea treats tinnitus.

 

 

SWEET BAY

SEE: BAY LEAF

 

SWEET CICELY

Digestive aid. Treats heartburn, acid indigestion, abdominal cramps, and intestinal gas. Stimulates appetite.

 

 

SWEET FERN

Resin is used to expel intestinal parasites and worms. Treats coughs and soothes mucous membranes. Digestive aid.

 

 

SWEET FLAG

Antioxidant. Analgesic. Anti-inflammatory. Neuroprotective. Treats painful neuropathy, headaches, and migraines. Lowers blood sugar levels. Extracts have shown an ability to protect against gamma radiation-induced cellular DNA damage. Root extracts have been used in the treatment of saw-scaled viper envenomations. Root extracts also treat and heal external wounds.

 

 

SWEET LEAF

SEE: STEVIA

 

 

SWEET POTATO

SEE: POTATO

 

 

SWEET VIOLET

SEE: VIOLET

 

 

SWEETGUM

Modern source of resin. Antimicrobial. Antiseptic. Anti-inflammatory. Protects the liver against chemical attack. Used in benzoin and as a fragrance in soaps and perfumes. Also used to flavor foods.

 

 

SWISS CHARD

SEE: BEET

 

SWORDFISH

 

Good protein source. High in beneficial omega-3 fatty acids that help support the brain, nervous system, and prostate. Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, dementia, and Alzheimers disease. Rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Fish oil may help maintain insulin levels in diabetics and improve breathing in asthma sufferers. Swordfish may contain high levels of mercury and should be consumed sparingly.

 

 




 

T



 

TAHEEBO

 

SEE: PAU D'ARCO

 

TAMARIND

Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Analgesic. Treats mild constipation and burning fevers. Can reduce blood sugar levels in diabetics. Shown to significantly lower total serum cholesterol and triglycerides, lower harmful LDL, and raise beneficial HDL levels. Lowers diastolic blood pressure. Muscle relaxant. Helpful for the obese. The fruit is used as a laxative. Seed extracts are insecticidal and have shown promise in the treatment of viper toxins. Seed extracts are also anti-ulcer and anti-tumor. Cancer cell inhibitor. Protects the liver and kidneys against chemical attack. Leaf extracts may be helpful in treating septic arthritis. Extracts may also be helpful in the treatment of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Tamarind seed extracts have been used as skin lightening agents. The seed kernel is a source of thickening and stabilizing agents in different foods. The fruit pulp is used in beverages, curries, sauces, and ice cream.

 

 

TANGERINE

Tea made from peels provides relief from aching muscles and bones due to fever or flu. Peel extracts help lower cholesterol levels.

 

 

TAPIOCA

Soothes intestinal tract. Cooked pudding is used to treat and heal stomach ulcers and colitis. Root is used as a poultice for skin eruptions such as eczema, boils, abscesses, and herpes lesions. Used by nursing mothers as a poultice for sore breasts and nipples.

 

 

 

TARO

High in fiber which helps increase elimination. High in Vitamin E which helps the body synthesize red blood cells, inhibits free radicals that can harm cells, helps the body to use Vitamin K, and protects the heart. Poi, a starchy paste made from taro, has shown the ability to inhibit the growth of colon cancer tumors.



 

TARRAGON

Antifungal. Anti-inflammatory. High in Vitamin B6 which is critical for protein and red blood cell metabolism, for the proper functioning of the nervous and immune systems, for the maintenance of blood sugar levels, and may be protective against some cancers (e.g. colorectal and lung). High in potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure, promote a steady heartbeat, and lower your risk of stroke. Lowers blood sugar levels. Anticonvulsant. Treats epileptic seizures and convulsions. Nervous system regulator and sedative. Tea treats insomnia and hyperactivity. In vinegar, used to improve digestion, stimulate bowels, and promote appetite. Some studies have shown that diets containing high amounts of tarragon are associated with a higher risk of liver damage and cancer.


 

 

TEA

Tea contains natural salicylates (aspirin). Antibacterial. Antiviral. Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Diuretic. High in quercetin, a natural antioxidant, anti-inflammatory and antihistamine, which is helpful for those with allergies and respiratory problems. Quercetin also protects cells against DNA and UV-induced sunlight damage, helps prevent alcohol-induced liver disease, lowers your blood pressure and risk of heart disease and stroke, lowers blood sugar and cholesterol, protects against tumors and ulcers, is neuroprotective, and inhibits cancer. May lower cholesterol and strengthen blood vessels of the heart. Helps to relieve migraines (caffeine constricts blood vessels in the head). Caffeine promotes the burning of fat. Teas contain tannins which are binding and help treat diarrhea. Tea leaves are neuroprotective. Daily tea consumption (any type) can help reduce cognitive decline and lessen depression. Reduces cavities and plaque buildup. May help to prevent heart and liver disease. Tea consumption is associated with a significantly reduced risk for lung cancer. Some evidence suggests that tea consumption is protective against oral cancers. Helps reduce rheumatoid arthritis and osteoporosis. Tea leaves can be used to treat itchy insect bites. The tannic acid in tea can be used to soothe itchy insect bites by neutralizing the venom. This same tannic acid will also help cool a sunburn, and eliminate odors when used as a foot soak. There is some evidence that tea polyphenols, used topically, may be beneficial in reducing sebum secretion and in treatment of acne. Some teas are higher in caffeine than others. Excessive caffeine can cause insomnia, and make you lose too much water and potentially stress the kidneys. Very hot tea consumption can increase your risk of gastric and esophageal cancers.

Black tea (red tea in China) is highly fermented and high in flavenoids, which are potent antioxidants that can help reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke. Some evidence suggests that black teas may inhibit oxidative damage in smokers and also inhibit tumor growth in colon, lung, and ovarian cancers. Black tea can lower total and LDL cholesterol and triglyceride levels. Lowers blood pressure and blood sugar levels. Helpful for diabetics because it increases insulin activity. Treats diarrhea. Neuroprotective. Black tea consumption can help reduce the risk of Alzheimers and Parkinsons disease. Extracts have also shown the ability to inactivate botulinim toxins and protect the liver against arsenic and dioxin poisoning. Black tea extracts have also been shown to reduce mercury absorption from contaminated fish. Antimicrobial. Ulcer healer. Extracts have also been used in mouthwashes. Helpful for the obese. Reduces cavities and can help you keep your teeth longer. Helps reduce anxiety. Black teas have a higher caffeine content than other teas.

Green tea is unfermented and considered to be more healthful than black tea due to its increased vitamin and tannin content. Green tea is made from mature tea leaves. Antibacterial. Antiviral. Anti-inflammatory. Analgesic. Lowers blood pressure, blood sugar levels, triglycerides, and cholesterol. Green tea has been shown to protect retinal cells from ultraviolet radiation, and reduce DNA damage caused by sunlight. Extracts protect against oral, esophageal, stomach, lung, liver, kidney, endometrial, colorectal, bladder, breast, skin, prostate, ovarian, blood (leukemia), cervical, and pancreatic cancers. Some studies suggest a protective effect of green tea against hematologic neoplasms, especially acute myeloid leukemias. Helpful for smokers and the obese. Helpful for diabetics because it increases insulin activity. Lowers stroke risk. May be helpful in the treatment of asthma. Reduces fatigue, stress, and depression. Green tea compounds are neuroprotective. Helpful in the treatment of diabetic neuropathy. May also be helpful in the treatment of Alzheimers disease and autoimmune diseases such as lupus. Enhances memory and cognitive brain function, and helps prevent age-related bone loss in the elderly. Green tea consumption may be protective against age-related cataracts. Compounds in green tea have been shown to stimulate hair growth as well as protect the liver and kidneys by detoxifying and removing toxic substances such as cigarette smoke solvents, PCBs, alcohol, drugs, heavy metals, lead, arsenic, and dioxin. Green tea can also help protect newborns against perinatal nicotine-induced oxidative stress. Green tea extracts have also been shown to reduce mercury absorption from contaminated fish and protect blood cells against asbestos injury. Treats arthritis, gastritis, and hepatitis. Also treats infections and inflammation of the stomach, lower intestines, colon, and liver. Kidney, heart, and liver protector. Tumor inhibitor. Green tea extracts may also be helpful in the treatment of acne, genital warts, chronic fatigue, gingivitis, hyperalgesia, and pharyngitis. Extracts can also help hasten the healing of external wounds. A green tea mouthwash can inhibit the growth of periodontal bacteria, and can also help control postoperative pain after impacted molar surgery. Green tea ointment can help relieve episiotomy pain and improve wound healing in first-time mothers. Extracts can also help reduce gingival bleeding after tooth extractions. Extracts have shown promise in the treatment of insect-vectored diseases such as leishmaniasis. Green tea compounds have shown an ability to inhibit intestinal parasites such as roundworms. Protects the heart, kidneys, and liver against chemical poisonings. Green tea extracts can also protect and maintain renal function during malaria infection Green tea may be protective against the oxidative stress and DNA damage generated by exposure to the electromagnetic fields of high-voltage power lines. Low-caffeine green tea may help improve sleep quality in the elderly. Green tea is low in caffeine, but doesnt stay fresh long. Excessive consumption of green tea may be a risk factor for periodontal disease. Some Chinese studies have suggested that green tea drinkers have an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

Oolong tea is a partially fermented version of green tea. Antioxidant. Cancer cell inhibitor. Lowers triglycerides and cholesterol. Helps increase metabolic rate, burn fat, and reduce excess weight. Helpful for diabetics because it increases insulin activity. Treats allergic skin reactions such as atopic dermatitis lesions. Treats stress. Oolong tea can also soothe stubborn eczema.

White tea is minimally processed and has the least caffeine but is high in antioxidants. White tea is made from the buds and leaves of young tea plants. Neuroprotective. Lowers blood sugar. Colon cancer cell inhibitor. Protects the liver against chemical assault. Extracts are also gastroprotective, and may be helpful in the treatment of gastric ulcers. Protects cells against DNA damage. Helpful for diabetics and the obese. Also lowers triglyceride levels. White tea consumption may improve prediabetes-induced reproductive function. Steep in cold water to maximize antioxidant benefits. White peony, a type of fermented white tea, may be protective against alcoholic liver injury.

Yellow tea is unfermented and processed similarly to green tea, but differs in the drying process. Compounds in yellow tea may be more potent than other teas in protecting the liver against chemical attack. Lowers blood sugar levels, triglycerides, and cholesterol.



 

TEA TREE

Broad-spectrum antibiotic. Natural antiseptic. Treats acne, staph infections, athlete's foot, nail fungus, yeasts, and antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Antifungal. Natural deodorant. Used as a skin cleanser and shampoo. Treats dandruff and reduces scalp irritation. Add a drop of tea tree oil to toothpaste when gums are inflamed. Treats oral candidiasis (thrush). Used in mouthwashes for bad breath. Also treats infant colic, migraine headaches, earaches, aching muscles, diaper rash, sore throat, heat rash, acne, cuts and abrasions, mouth ulcers, warts, yeast infections, sunburn, sinus and lung congestion, leg cramps, minor burns, bed sores, and herpes lesions. Tea tree oil has shown some effectiveness against human head lice. May cause skin irritation in some sensitive individuals. Tea tree oil is highly toxic and should never be taken internally.

 

 

TEAK

Antioxidant. Floral extracts are anti-inflammatory and analgesic. Bark extracts treat diabetes. Helps lower blood sugar levels and cholesterol. Leaf extracts can be used externally as a wound healer.

 

 

THYME

Potent antioxidant. Excellent antibiotic. Antiseptic. Analgesic. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Anti-inflammatory. Lowers blood pressure. Aflatoxin inhibitor. High in iron and calcium. Iron vitalizes blood cells and keeps your immune system healthy. Calcium helps form and preserve teeth and bones and prevent osteoporosis. Treats bacterial, fungal, and viral infections. Treats amoebic dysentery. In tea or drink, reduces symptoms of colds, influenza, fever, and allergies. Used as a gargle for sore throats and as a mouthwash for bad breath, tooth decay, and cold sores. Hot chest compresses are used to break up phlegm and lung congestion in asthmatics and bronchitis sufferers. Cancer cell inhibitor (e.g. colon). Thyme oil (thymol) can protect the liver and kidneys against chemical attack. Thyme extracts can also protect the liver against parasitic Toxoplasma infections. Thymol has also shown promise in the treatment of intestinal parasites such as tapeworms. Warm tea treats migraine headaches and stomach cramps. Relieves symptoms of colic and flatulence. Treats dysmennorrhea. Extracts help improve learning and memory deficits, and may also be useful in the treatment of Alzheimers disease. Crushed leaves can be used to treat insect bites and stings. Lotion is used to soothe aching joints and muscles, and for treating fungal infections such as athlete's foot, nail fungus, and vaginal yeast infections. An eyewash can be used to reduce irritation due to chlorinated swimming pools. Combined as a paste with lime juice, onion juice, and honey, treats festering sores and boils. Used as a food preservative. Healing massage oil. Water purifier. Some people may be allergically sensitive to thyme.

 

 

 

TINOSPORA

Indian herb helps regulates blood sugar levels in diabetics. Diuretic.

 

 

TOADFLAX

Diuretic. Diaphoretic. Used in internal cleansings to increase the body's ability to sweat out toxins. Anti-inflammatory. Mild laxative. Used internally to treat urinary tract disorders. Digestive aid. Helps eliminate kidney stones. Treatment for dropsy and jaundice. Used externally in poultices to treat skin problems and hemorrhoids.

 

 

 

TOBACCO

Chewed tobacco is actually a good topical treatment for skin itchiness and pain. Unfortunately, the list is long for the numerous negative side effects of chewing, inhaling, or smoking tobacco products. These include, but are not limited to mouth, tongue, esophageal, throat, pharyngeal, laryngeal, lymph, bladder, kidney, ovarian, prostate, pancreatic, stomach, liver, colorectal, breast, and lung cancers, myeloid leukemia, diabetes, heart disease, senile cataracts and dementia, periodontal disease, hearing loss, and respiratory diseases such as asthma, bronchitis, emphysema, and pneumonia.

Smoking has been associated with an increased risk of developing certain neurological diseases such as multiple sclerosis. Pregnant smokers have an increased risk for having a low birth weight or preterm baby, or of having a baby born with specific birth defects such as an oral cleft. Mothers who use tobacco products should not breastfeed. Non-smoking pregnant women who are exposed to tobacco smoke have a higher risk of having a spontaneous abortion or a stillbirth especially after the first trimester. Children have a higher risk of developing asthmatic symptoms even at low levels of exposure to cigarette smoke. Studies have also shown that passive smoking may increase the risk of malignant lymphomas in pet cats as well. Smoking cigarettes has been implicated in higher rates of erectile dysfunction in men.

Tobacco also contains nicotine, a chemical stimulant that is as addictive as heroin or cocaine. When burned and inhaled, cigars and cigarettes also produce additional toxic substances such as lead. Arsenic, cadmium, chromium, nickel, and lead are among the heavy metals present in cigarettes. There are an estimated 4,000 substances present in tobacco cigarette smoke (nicotine is the most prevalent). The heavy use of snuff (oral tobacco) has been linked to severe malformations in the developing fetus. Smokeless tobacco is also associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. Chronic tobacco consumption is one of the leading causes of premature death in people worldwide.

 

 

TOFU

SEE: SOY

 

 

TOMATO

Rich in antioxidants. Contains natural salicylates (aspirin). Inhibits tumor growth and may prevent radiation-induced DNA damage. Lowers blood pressure. Lowers total cholesterol and triglycerides and increases beneficial HDL cholesterol levels. Tomato paste is one of the richest sources of lycopene, a potent antioxidant, which has been found to be protective against heart disease, myocardial infarction, cataracts, diabetes, and numerous cancers including skin, colorectal, gastric, lung, breast, pancreatic, ovarian, cervical, prostate, liver, and bladder. Due to processing methods, the lycopene found in tomato paste is actually more bioavailable to the body than it is in raw tomatoes. Lycopene can also protect the liver and kidneys against radiation damage and chemical attack. Lycopene is also an ulcer and tumor inhibitor, and is protective against gastric ulcers and gastroesophageal reflex disease. Higher serum lycopene levels can also reduce the risk of stroke and mortality from metabolic syndrome. Lycopene may be helpful in treating infertile men who have a low sperm count. Lycopene is also neuroprotective, and may protect against age-associated memory loss and cognitive defects. Strengthens the male reproductive system. Tomato paste is also one of the highest known natural sources of Vitamin E which helps the body synthesize red blood cells, inhibits free radicals that can harm cells, helps the body to use Vitamin K, and protects the heart. Additionally, tomato paste is among the richest sources of potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure, promote a steady heartbeat, and lower your risk of stroke. Cooked tomato paste also contains naringenin, a neuroprotective flavenoid that helps expel intestinal parasites and worms. Naringenin treats gout arthritis, and also has also shown an ability to protect the liver and kidneys against chemical exposure. Naringenin may also be effective in inhibiting infections caused by coronaviruses including COVID-19. Tomato paste may also offer protection against toxic lead accumulation in the blood. Tomato compounds can also protect the liver against neurodegeneration caused by mercury accumulation. Rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Tomatoes are a good source of beta-carotene and Vitamin C. Beta-carotene can help prevent the development of eye diseases such as cataracts and macular degeneration. Beta-carotene also offers protection against UV-induced sunlight damage. Vitamin C boosts the immune system, helps lower blood pressure, and has been used in the prevention and treatment of many cancers. Some tomato varieties (e.g. cherry) have been shown to be neuroprotective, and may be helpful in the treatment of amnesia and Alzheimers disease. Tomatoes have been shown to offer protection against UV sunlight damage. High in folic acid (Vitamin B9) which is essential for DNA synthesis and repair, and has been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, fetal neural tube defects, cervical dysplasia, heart disease, bowel problems, and certain cancers (e.g. oral, pharyngeal, bladder, colorectal, and pancreas). Contains natural chlorine and sulphur, which helps stimulate and protect liver function. Tomato consumption may be protective against the decline in skeletal muscle strength associated with aging. Tomato juice helps accelerate the production of blood sugar in hypoglycemics, and has been shown to regenerate new liver tissue. Tomato juice consumption can reduce blood pressure levels in the elderly, and may also help improve sperm motility in infertile men. Helps dissolve fat after a fatty meal. Treats nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Tomato intake may offer protection against the development of liver cancer, particularly among individuals without chronic infection with hepatitis B virus. Good for aches and general pain relief. Powdered seeds are used as an ideal protein supplement for athletes. In dried form, used as an effective antidiarrheal. A poultice of leaf extracts can be used to promote the healing of open wounds and sores. Leaves and vines are considered poisonous and should not be consumed. Keep in mind that some members of the nightshade family, which includes tomatoes, eggplants, peppers, and potatoes, have been known to provoke allergic reactions in some sensitive individuals when consumed in sufficient quantities. Tomato ketchup paste may be high in sodium which can be a major contributor to hypertension in salt-sensitive individuals. High salt diets can also deplete the bodys calcium levels, which can increase the risk of developing osteoporosis.



 

TORMENTIL

Antiseptic. Strong antioxidant. Treats irritable bowel syndrome. Used as an astringent to treat diarrhea, dysentery, and hemorrhaging. Used in gargles to cure mouth ulcers. Treats toothache pain.

 

 

 

TREE TURMERIC

Contains berberine, a potent antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory, which is used to treat intestinal and parasitic infections including malaria, trypanosomiasis, trachoma, leishmaniasis, schistosomiasis, and cholera. Berberine lowers cholesterol, burns fat, treats metabolic syndrome and diabetic neuropathy, and also helps lower blood sugar levels in diabetics. Berberine is neuroprotective, protects against heavy metals-induced memory impairment, and has shown an ability to inhibit the growth of cancerous cells. Berberine treats liver fibrosis, and can also protect the liver and kidneys against chemical attack. Berberine may also be effective in treating benign prostatic hyperplasia. Do not exceed the recommended dosage of berberine. Berberine is not recommended for pregnant women.

 

 

 

TRITICALE

Reduces blood sugar and cholesterol. Helps prevent heart disease. Increases bowels.

 

 

 

TROUT

Good protein source. High in beneficial omega-3 fatty acids, which help support the brain, nervous system, and prostate. Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, dementia, and Alzheimers disease. Rich source of Vitamin B12 which is essential in the production of red and white blood cells, maintenance of a healthy nervous system, and may be helpful in the prevention of dementia. Rich source of Vitamin D which is essential for cell replication, calcium absorption and metabolism, normal insulin secretion, and bone health. Vitamin D also provides protection against bone diseases, many cancers, multiple sclerosis, diabetes, gum disease, and muscle problems. Good source of Vitamin A which helps form and maintain teeth, tissues, and skin. Vitamin A also produces pigments that are essential for good vision. Anti-inflammatory. Lowers blood pressure. Trout is high in cholesterol. Used as a treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, but not recommended if you have gout.

 

 

 

TRUE INDIGO

Antioxidant. Antibacterial. Used in Chinese medicine to treat leukemia. Leaves are neuroprotective. Enhances cognition. May be helpful in the treatment of Alzheimers disease. Protects the liver against chemical attack. The active component is indirubin.

 

 

TULIP

Bulbs treat toothache and insect bite pain.

 

 

TUNA

 

Good protein source. High in beneficial omega-3 fatty acids, which help support the brain, nervous system, and prostate. Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to be protective against cognitive decline, dementia, and Alzheimers disease. Rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Tuna is a good source of Vitamin B12 which is essential in the production of red and white blood cells, maintenance of a healthy nervous system, and may be helpful in the prevention of dementia. Rich source of Vitamin D which is essential for cell replication, calcium absorption and metabolism, normal insulin secretion, and bone health. Vitamin D also provides protection against bone diseases, many cancers, multiple sclerosis, diabetes, gum disease, and muscle problems. Some varieties (e.g. skipjack) help improve memory deficits and may be useful in the treatment of dementia and Alzheimers disease. Lowers blood pressure and cholesterol. Anti-inflammatory. May protect the heart against sudden attack. Tuna oil has been shown to reduce the incidence and severity of heart arrhythmias. Fish oil may help maintain insulin levels in diabetics and improve breathing in asthma sufferers. Also treats acute respiratory distress syndrome, psoriasis, multiple sclerosis, and dysmennorrhea. Canned tuna is safe to eat because the canning process destroys any microorganisms that may be present. Processed (e.g. canned) tuna products can be high in sodium which can be a major contributor to hypertension in salt-sensitive individuals. High salt diets can also deplete the bodys calcium levels, which can increase the risk of developing osteoporosis. Treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, but not recommended if you have gout. Fresh and canned tuna can also contain high levels of mercury and should be consumed sparingly. In general, larger species tend to have higher concentrations of accumulated mercury in their tissues.

 

 

 

 

TURKEY

Great protein source. Rich source of Vitamin B12 which is essential in the production of red and white blood cells, maintenance of a healthy nervous system, and may be helpful in the prevention of dementia. Rich in selenium, which is vital for a normal functioning immune system and thyroid, helps prevent atherosclerosis, arthritis, and cognitive decline, alleviates menopausal symptoms, promotes a healthy central nervous system and prostate, and may offer some cancer protection (e.g. breast, bladder, colon). Good source of iron, which vitalizes blood cells and keeps your immune system healthy. Turkey is high in cholesterol.

 

 

TURKEYBERRY

Antioxidant. Anti-inflammatory. Antimicrobial. Antiviral. Analgesic. Extracts are used in the treatment of pain. Treats hypertension. Lowers blood pressure and blood sugar levels.

 

 

 

TURKEY CORN

Extracts treat digestive problems, urinary tract disorders, menstrual difficulties, and skin rashes. Diuretic.

 

 

 

TURMERIC

Powerful antioxidant. Antimicrobial. Anticoagulant. Anti-inflammatory. Antibacterial. Antifungal. Antiviral. Analgesic. Liver detoxifier. Provides support for the liver and gallbladder. Breaks down carcinogens and other toxins. Tumor and ulcer suppressor. Inhibits breast, oral, prostate, gastric, lung, pancreatic, liver, and colon cancers. Stimulates bile secretion. Contains natural salicylates (aspirin). Lowers blood sugar levels and cholesterol. Ground turmeric is high in potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure, promote a steady heartbeat, and lower your risk of stroke. Increases digestive enzymes. Increases appetite. Inhibits gas and relieves heartburn and indigestion. Kills parasites. May help offset the spiciness or hotness of foods such as chili peppers. Reduces bleeding during pregnancy. Helps regulate insulin levels in diabetics, reduce proteinuria, and prevent diabetic nephropathy. Used in India to treat anorexia and rheumatism. Extracts have also been used to treat irritable bowel syndrome, colitis, cataracts, and pulmonary fibrosis. Turmeric oil is a natural mosquito repellent. Anti-aging. Helpful for the obese. Improves cognition. May be helpful as an anticonvulsive, and in the treatment of seizures and chronic epilepsy. Diets rich in curcumin, the active compound found in turmeric, are both neuroprotective and radioprotective, and have been found to inhibit Alzheimers, Parkinsons, and Crohns disease symptoms. Curcumin may also be helpful in treating viral diseases as COVID-19. Curcumin helps lower blood pressure and cholesterol levels, and has shown much promise as an effective cancer cell inhibitor. Curcumin is one of the most potent anti-inflammatory substances ever studied. Curcumin has shown the ability to protect the blood, heart, brain, liver, lungs, and kidneys against chemical assault, and to provide protection and repair DNA damage caused by lead, cadmium, or arsenic exposure. Curcumin may be helpful in treating nonalcoholic liver disease, and is protective against liver fibrosis. Curcumin may also be helpful in reducing the harmful effects of chloroform, a by-product of water chlorination. Curcumin is antiviral, and may also be helpful in treating and preventing fatigue, chronic stress, major depression, cognitive dysfunction, memory disorders, epileptic seizures, cerebral ischemia, stroke, sepsis, asthma symptoms, benign prostatic hyperplasia, vaginal candidiasis, chronic alcoholism, rheumatoid and osteoarthritis, and the motor disorder tardive dyskinesia. Curcumin can help reduce the severity of PMS symptoms. Curcumin is protective against renal fibrosis, and can also protect the kidneys against the harmful side effects of high fructose corn syrup consumption. Curcumin has been shown to reduce the formation of heterocyclic amines which are considered to be carcinogenic substances produced by the cooking process. Curcumin can protect brain cells against the damage caused by the long term use of morphine. Curcumin can also protect brain tissue against oxidative stress induced by gasoline fumes inhalation. Curcumin has also shown promise in the treatment of insect-vectored diseases such as leishmaniasis and trypanosomiasis. Shown to eliminate worms caused by schistosomiasis. Aids wound healing and muscle regeneration. Treats symptoms of snake envenomations including edema, hemorrhage, and necrosis. Reduces swelling in bruises, wounds, and insect bites. Provides relief from sprains, swollen joints, fractures, and tendonitis. Treats allergic disorders such as food allergies. Comparable to cortisone. Curcumin mixed with bromelain (from pineapples) has been used to treat lupus. Curcumin is also an aflatoxin inhibitor. Curcumin has been shown to reduce skin and other tumors when used topically. Curcumin cosmetic creams have anti-aging and anti-wrinkling properties. Turmeric extract creams have also been used to help reduce sebum secretions and treat acne. Powdered curcumin roots or gel treats skin ulcers, pimples, dermatitis, eczema, psoriasis, and diaper rash. Curcumin can also treat gingivitis, and suppress the adherence to tooth surfaces by Streptococcus mutans bacteria, the suspected causative agents of dental caries. Curcumin gels have also been used to treat periodontitis. Topically used as a paste with lime juice to heal herpes lesions, leprosy sores, measles, mumps, and chicken pox. The topical use of curcumin or turmeric may also be helpful in treating oral mucositis. Also used in creams to accelerate the healing of Caesarean incision scars. Turmeric is also used to increase the shelf life of some oils, fats, and seafood. Found in many mustards. Breath freshener. Large doses of turmeric may cause stomach distress. Heavy turmeric consumption can also increase urinary oxalate levels, which can increase the risk of kidney stones in some individuals. Should not be used in combination with other anticoagulants such as aspirin, garlic, ginkgo, or Vitamin E.

 

 

TURNIP

Antioxidant. Neuroprotective. Can protect against breast, colon, and stomach cancer. Used for angina pain relief. Great calcium source. Calcium helps form and preserve teeth and bones and prevent osteoporosis. High in magnesium, which is a natural tranquilizer and helps the body to regulate cholesterol and blood sugar levels. Magnesium is also good for relief of migraines and helps slow bone loss. High in Vitamin K which is essential in the production of blood clotting proteins, improves bone metabolism, and has been shown to have anti-cancer effects (e.g. Non-Hodgkins lymphoma). Turnip greens are also rich in lutein, a carotenoid which accumulates in the retina.
